The problem mainly was the fact that the concierge agent did not understanding what the tour was going to be like and he sold it to us as if he had done it him self and loved it!  This was the only bad experience we had for the 3 days at the hilton but it was a whole day of our trip that was not fun.

Great location near Penn Station, hotel is very modern and tastefully furnished. The Keurig coffee makers in the room are fantastic. The bar is great and so is the quality of food. But beware of any interaction with the hotel staff, extremely unfriendly and indifferent. I am Hilton Diamond and except for the free breakfast voucher the check in staff would care less - not even a bottle of water in the room! While the location of the hotel and the contemporary / update furnishing something worth considering but I was very disappointed with the hotel staff.

We had a very enjoyable experience staying here. After staying in Times Square for a few days, we wanted to stay somewhere that was still inherently New York but was away from the hustle and bustle.Location - 5 minutes walk to the F line subway station, 15 minutes walk to Chelsea market, 30 minute walk to Times square. There's so much to do in Chelsea! There's awesome cafes, restaurants and bars all around Chelsea and the High Line is around a 15-20 minute walk away. Service- Staff were really friendly and approachable.Room - the room was not big but reasonable sized by New York standards. We loved the little touches like having a coffee machine in the room which I have never seen before. The room was also spotlessly clean. There is a nice roof top bar at the top of the hotel but its quite unique in that you have to ask the concierge that you would like to get access to the bar then staff from the bar will come down and collect you (perhaps this is to weed off non Hilton guests?)Tip - The hotel can help you arrange transport to the airport however I believe there are other shuttle services which do hotel to airport pickups (much cheaper if you were travelling alone or as a couple) however you would have to book it yourself.

For years, I have stayed at the Affinia, across from Madison Square Garden, but the Hilton Fashion is a much better choice. Sure the walk is longer, but it takes you away from the madness of MSG and nearby Times Square, so all the better. The Hilton is also close to some great antique markets, the High Line, and the better restaurants of Chelsea and beyond. The hotel itself is great, down a quiet 26th street off the busy 7th Ave. The rooms are new, clean, and large for NYC. Street noise is as quiet as it gets, but the hall and adjoining room noise can get a bit louder than you like. Doesn't that always seem to be the case, though? All in all, a solid choice.

Stayed at the hotel for one week with some friends. 3rd time in NYC and also the 3rd hotel in order. Price was good for the standard of the place compared to the other Manhattan hotels I've been staying at. Rooms are a bit small but that is very common on Manhattan. And you don't really stay in the room much. Our room was at the back of the building with basically no view other then another building close by. Our other friends had a street room with a more nice view although more noise from the street.Pros: Helpful staff, beds were big and comfortable, bathroom was clean and fresh. Only ate at the resturant for breakfast but it was good. Their rooftop bar is a nice place to hang out with pretty good views, (although they serve the drinks in plastic glasses which is a bit bad for the feeling). The bar at the lobby is also nice.Location was nice, not as busy as higher up in Midtown. But still a lot of nice places close by and subway 2 blocks up on 28th street. But walked to most places from the hotel.Cons: Heating/Air con was a really stupid system that bursted out hot air when it feeled that the temperature had dropped below the setting. It also made a lot of noice and the air got really dry. As it seemed to be a fairly new hotel you would have thought that this could have been better. But I have the impression that this is quite the norm, in NY at least.The maid insisted of making the bed with the feet side at the head side even though it seemed obvious that it should not be like that, and that i turned it around every time. Doors "leaked" a lot of noise in from the corridor, so you could hear your neighbors when they entered/leaved their rooms quite clearly. But did not get bothered by it.Overall: Fresh hotel with all the things you need. I could come back here no problem the next time!

Stayed at the Hilton Fashion District for several nights. The hotel was very clean and well taken care of. Rooms were small but Nice, The rooftop bar was great, it was fully enclosed in glass panels due to the weather but still had an outdoor feel.

We stayed here just before Xmas to take the youngest daughter shopping. Great location, within easy walking distance of Macy's and 5th Avenue. Staff were really helpful & pleasant. Restaurant good, if a little unremarkable. I normally stay in the Hilton on Avenue of the Americas, when working in NY, but Hilton Fashion District was a lot cheaper and great.

We spent valentine's day and 2 more nights there, and booked superior rooms on high floors, to have more chance to get a room with a nice view....and were highly disappointed..... We booked 2 rooms, as we got there with another couple of our friends. Not only (reservations were on the same name and made at the same moment...3 months before...) couldn't we get rooms together or even at the same floor... But they told us they have only one room facing north (to see the Empire...), but told us, no problem, that way, you'll have one with a view north, and one south...well, we thought ground zero was south...it is actually, but there was a big wall in between, even on our 18th-high floor... So we had a glass at the rooftop bar to enjoy the view. The hotel was nice, the concierge tried to be helpful, but they pushed the hopes to high. The restaurant "Rare" btw is really very good. I'd recommend the hotel as any other one, the view would be a cherry on top, but don't go there expecting it, there are far many chances not to see anything from the room, except a wall.

I love this Hotel....Hilton spared no expense for the less then $100 I paid. Kerig, in rm vending machine, rm service ice, two bars, 2 full length mirrors, cordless phone, computer in tv......Great value and location.....food was tasty.....close to mega bus stop, Wendy Williams and Rachel Ray. Added bonus local eatery Soul Fixins

stayed here for one night and had no idea how close this was to times square! perfect location, but be careful walking back at late at night...would not recommend doing that alone. otherwise, this hotel was perfect. brand new, very clean. of course the rooms were not huge, you can't expect that in NYC, but it was very clean and the people were nice. plus, we were on the 17th floor and looked right out to the Empire State Building, it was a beautiful view!

This is a great hotel for business travellers and tourists, the rooms are large (by NYC standards) and are well appointed with a fashion twist. The area is great for Midtown, the Village and Chelsea but you can also take the train from the nearby stations. There is a fully stocked fridge, tea and coffee maker as well as a large flat screen tv.The only thing I would change is the ironing board, for some reason they give you a mini one which you have to balance on the desk rather than a full size one that has legs on the floor. But I'm sure if you ask they will send you a proper one.

Stayed here for a week, got a very good rate off Expedia. We were pleasantly surprised to find that the room was very spacious for New York City standards. Bathrooms were very clean, bed very comfortable. Keurig coffee machine with complimentary coffee and tea in room which was nice. We would have rated this hotel higher if it wasn't for the fact that the staff were such a let-down. The lobby staff were lukewarm at best, and the receptionists were aloof and disinterested. This hotel could be so much better if management trained staff or got rid of receptionists who weren't interested in their jobs, considering competition in NYC is so fierce. Not the standard you would expect from Hilton staff. We rang up wanting some more coffee delivered to our room, only be be greeted by "What do you want?" in a rude, bored tone. Everything was a bother and nobody seemed interested in helping or being friendly at the receptionist desk. How appalling… If it weren't for the reception staff, we would stay here again but as it is, we would not return or recommend it. Pick up your act, Hilton!

I went here around Veteran's Day for business, and it was good enough hotel. The room was a decent size for one person, maybe even two. It's definitely a business hotel with people always on their phones, laptops -- on the go and not too many families around. Being that it's in the fashion district, the lobby and overall hotel presentation (as you can see from the hotel photos) is modern and hip. Even if it's on an off-street from Fashion Avenue, you get a lot of noise, but maybe it's because I was on the second floor right above the front entrance so I could hear people taking smoke breaks, taxi drivers pull up on the drive way, doormen, trucks delivering things for the restaurant downstairs, etc. So if you are looking for peace and quiet and a feeling of privacy, probably not your hotel, although they have a fresh pair of ear plugs on your nightstand every night. However the room itself was clean and comfortable. Nice bed and clean bathroom. A big plus about this place is LOCATION. You are very close to a lot of attractions and also to transportation hubs (Penn Station is right down the street). Everything is pretty much in walking distance. Overall, I would probably come here again for the right price, and if my room was higher than the 2nd floor and not over the front entrance. The staff -- the doormen, reception and restaurant staff were very friendly and helpful. ALSO the rooftop bar is fun and had great cocktails.

This hotel is nice, friendly staff, decent size room etc. The location is nice, espically if you want to shop. However, it is nothing amazing but the price wasn’t out of this world either which made it good for a short stay!

A decent hotel, comparable with other Hilton properties. The room was a good size, the hotel was clean, the location was good, and the staff was friendly. But nothing out of the ordinary and you would be better off staying at the Hilton Garden Inn 2 blocks away with comparable rooms for a lower price (and free internet service).

This hotel is proof that Hilton's brand names mean nothing. This is a full-service Hilton (as opposed to a budget Hilton Garden Inn, etc.)? Why? The rooms in this hotel are tiny -- as small as any hotel rooms I've stayed at in New York in years. Cramped hallways. The fixtures, like window-unit air conditioners, are out-of-date. The fitness center has limited facilities. The staff was perfectly friendly, but that's a given in better New York hotels these days. With the complete devaluation of the Hilton Hhonors program, I'm delighted that I won't need to seek out Hiltons anymore.

My husband and I stayed at the Hilton this past weekend for two nights. First off, the location is pretty good; you are close to Penn Station, FIT, the Flatiron and lots of shopping. The bell hop was very friendly and efficient and check-in was fairly quick and easy. The room was very nice and clean. Our king size bed was very comfortable. My favorite part of the room was the bathroom-newly updated, big, walk-in shower and lots of counter space. Our only issue was their seems to be a disconnect between the hotel and restaurant as far as room service goes. We called a couple days prior to arrange room service upon check-in and they forgot. Then the next morning our in-room dining breakfast came an hour late and was missing items. It wasn't that big of a deal but they should try and work out these kinks as it can get annoying. For the price and location I would recommend this hotel.

The rooms are beautifully designed and the staff is attractive and smart. Whomever designed the doors is the first cousin to satan! They are slammed all night by patrons (due to design). The cleaning crew no longer has carts (understandably heavy to lug around) but their closets are next to the room so they alternate the slamming and yelling in the hallways. All very festive!The last Saturday morning I was there after not sleeping I waited forever for the elevator in the hallways while listening to sounds of ecstasy from two different rooms. The doors are right next to each and there is nothing to buffer sound. So it's all rather X-rated.As I departed the cleaning person on this floor is yelling on her cell phone in the hallway.Give it some thought!Oddly, they are always pleased to explain how they can not possibly change your room. They seem sweetly overrun! Attractive staff, nice decorations but go only to party!
user_name:
Pat N
New York City, New York

review_body: My wife and I had some business in NYC and booked Hilton Fashion District as we had stayed here once before (don't think I reviewed) and saw a great price online. Less than I am used to paying for a decent hotel in Manhattan. There was a little confusion at check in when they didn't have the room class I had booked available (it was after 3pm) but we found something that worked. The rooms are a bit smaller than some NYC hotels (more like a european hotel) but very well equiped and a trendy modern look. We took the bed/breakfast option as I remembered that there was no great diner within a few blocks (unlike some hotels in NYC) and it was very good - good quality & good service. Others have commented on the location, which is almost across from FIT in Chelsea. My only advice would be to watch what room you are assigned. It is not a large hotel and with 3 elevators (great for getting up & down quickly) many are across from or behind the elevators. On a previous visit we were across from them and it was a bit noisy, especially if you don't sleep soundly. We stayed in the "11" line (1011) this time and it was great.Overall, a very safe bet for a great stay.

Despite a disappointing start to our holiday, we found availability at the Hilton Fashion district at short notice. We stayed during Hurricane Sandy's destructive visit. Throughout the entire stay staff was professional and very attentive. A special mention goes to the staff at the front desk who went to a lot of trouble to redirect a delayed package (due to Sandy's effects on deliveries) to me that arrived after we left.The hotel is well positioned to explore and experience the vastness of New York City. Its rooftop cocktail bar is a must as are the delicious burgers at "Rare". The room was a touch small but with very comfortable bed and amenities.Would definitely stay again.

We booked this hotel based on a AAA price deal we got, and having had such an excellent experience, we will definitely stay here again. We often stay in the city and go out of our way to be away from the tourist traps of Times Square. The Chelsea location was excellent for access to everywhere...we walked the 21 blocks to Central Park with ease, and the High Line and therefore Greenwich Village was just a few blocks away. As for the hotel itself, we were a little nervous as our room was directly opposite the elevators, but I can honestly say, we heard NO noise all night. We have stayed in other hotels in other cities and you can hear the elevators constantly. The front desk staff, including the bell hops who stored our luggage- free of charge, I must add-were courteous and friendly, and the room gave us everything we needed. We rally cannot complain about anything, and will be sure to stop here again.

this is my third time at this hotel. i am a customer for LIFE at this hotel when I travel to NYC. the Staff is top notch! they are friendly and professional and don't rest until its a perfect experience. The rooms are good size and the bed is super comfy. the cleanliness of the hotel is amazing. their rates are nominal to the area but the roof top bar always brings me back. I wholeheartedly require to stay at this hotel. You will not be disappointed. and if you do have any issues don't be afraid to get a manager and have them address the issues. I cant wait to get back to NYC to stay here again.

We travelled to New York in November 2012 and stayed at this lovely hotel. Rooms are modern and clean however typical NYC size. Our bed was sooooo comfortable and huge!! Staff were friendly and polite but the most annoying thing about the hotel was the lifts!!! The key cards don't seem to work and you can only get off on your own floor for security reasons!! This was very inconvenient when our party was spread over several floors!!! We also had a fire alarm that went of in the early hours of the morning. Normally I would mind such a prompt safety measure and it was reassuring to hear the reception staff speaking over a tannoy to let residents know what is happening but it went on forever and they could not turn it off!! The roof top bar gave the most spectacular views of the city and is well worth a trip although the drinks are a little expensive!! We only went for breakfast once which was a buffet style. Plenty of selection, hot and tasty!! All in all this is a nice hotel close to Times Square and local sub stations. We would defo go back.

I booked this hotel for Valentine's day weekend in the city with my wife and was not disappointed! The check-in process was quick, which was important as I was rushing to be on time for dinner reservations. We ordered room service a couple times during the weekend and they were very prompt and helpful. Would definitely stay again!

I spent here only one night but was positively impressed. I booked through the hilton website and the site gave me 199 USD for a guestroom. When I arrived the lobby and the rooms looked very modern and classy. Room was not big, but that can be expected in NYC but it was very well done. Nice view of the empire state building and surrounding areas. The hallways get a bit noisy sometimes when people are waiting for the elevators though. For the rest a good choice in NYC. I must say that the valet parking of 55 US was very expensive, but I did not have any other idea where to park the car, so I did it.

I stayed here while visiting NYC with work. Overall, not a bad place. The rooms are fine, if a bit smaller than a lot of other Hiltons I've stayed in. Bed was comfy and the noise from the street was not too bad (I was on the 9th floor).Reception staff were freindly and helpful, so no problems there.Breakfast was free, but I only had it once as they took so long to deliver the food I didn't really have time to eat it, and they forgot one of the items I ordered!Not a bad location, about a ten minute walk from Times Square and 5 minutes from the Flatiron building and 5 minutes from Maceys. Close to subway stops and plenty of places to eat.Overall - An adequate hotel without being anything special. If the rate is good - go for it.

After staying at the hilton in Quito the room here felt a little small but considering it was new york the size was fine. Room was nice and clean but a little noisy due to the traffic. I'm glad I was on the 14th floor as I bet the lower floors were very noisy, staff were pleasant but not overly helpful.Location was great- walked to most of the attractions both uptown and downtown and I felt safe there at night. Also good subway links if you don't feel like walking. Didn't try the breakfast- there are plenty of places near to get cheap nice breakfast including a good bagel and coffee shop on 8th- about 5-10 mins walk away. Would probably stay there again.

I recently stayed at the Hilton New York Fashion District>Things to love:- very comfortable room- I asked for a quiet location and even though only on the 4th floor was at the back and it was wonderfully quiet- comfortable king bed with lots of pillows and comfy duvet- adequate closet space with laptop friendly safe- Keurig coffee maker with 3 different types of K cups- nice big panel TV- bathroom -- shower with great pressure and nice toiletriesOther comments:- The room was very reasonably sized for NY- The bathroom was sized for 1 only -- but that was ok with me- New looking with nice design elements- they had popcorn at the front desk - seemed a bit odd and I didn't care for the smell much in the lobby but this was a small thing- The staff were most helpful and friendly- Good restaurant especially if you like gourmet burgers (Rare). Was very reasonable and good food- Nice bar area too- close to other dining, banking, shops- great area --- lots to do!I'll be back!

Tucked away in the fashion district, this Hilton is small, and yet, very comfortable. Slim, adequately facilitated by a restaurant and roof top bar, it feels more like a boutique hotel rather than a Hilton. Room was New York city standard size, although this one feels small but deliciously comfortable. Furnishings are new, and bathroom was newly refurbished. A little noisy in the morning. HHonors status, dont expect too much as they dont have executive lounge nor dedicated executive floor. This was one rare occasion where as a HHonors Gold I didnt get upgraded to the next best room. However, I'd still stay its good value for money.

The new Hilton in the Fashion district is a great location. Trendy, hip, small room - very "W Hotel" feel to it. It does not feel like a normal Hilton. The staff was friendly & the room service came SUPER fast (less than 20 minutes). The downside for me was I had a low level room (2nd floor) so I was kept awake all night long by street noise, car honks, etc. The rooms are very small but that's quite normal for Manhattan. The walls in this hotel are very thin so I heard every toilet flush, TV program and conversation of the rooms around me which is quite annoying when you're there for work and just need some sleep.

Clean hotel, very friendly staff. But I couldn't sleep because there is no insulation in the walls at all. It was really loud outside the whole night. Also, I could hear every phone conversation the guy in the next room had even though my bed was on the opposite wall. And the people in the other room sure flushed their toilet a lot.

My wife booked us a room at the Hilton Fashion District during our recent trip to New York. I don't recall how much we paid for 3 nights, but I recall it being a phenomenal price for New York City.The service here was great. Upon check-in, we were provided 2 bottles of water and some candy. In fact, anytime we asked for more bottled water, the front desk gladly provided it. Our room was also a great size (for NY standards). The room was clean and updated. The bed was comfortable, and the bathroom was updated. Everything about our room was very tastefully decorated, which we appreciated.Rather than going on and on about our room, all I can say is that we had an absolutely wonderful stay at the Hilton. Also, the hotel has a restaurant/bar in the lobby (which we did not get to try) as well as a bar on the roof. We did visit the top-level bar every night that we were there. Drinks were not outrageously expensive and it was never too packed for us to enjoy a drink or two.Also, we loved the location of our hotel. Since we flew into Newark Airport, we took a train from Newark to Penn Station. The hotel is a few blocks' walk to/from Penn Station. Also, the hotel is close to several subway stops, and is within walking distance of some great restaurants (we walked to Boqueria and Gramercy Tavern).If I had any complaints about our room, it is that the rooms facing 26th Street (such as ours) is a bit noisier since you hear a lot of traffic from the cars below. On our first night, we were awoken at 1 or 2am by a delivery truck that was honking its horn. If possible, I'd ask for a room that did not face 26th. Also, I believe that you have to pay for wifi in your room on a per-day AND per-device basis. However, they do have free wifi in the lobby, which was appreciated.All in all, I really did enjoy our stay at the Hilton and would recommend it to those looking for a reasonably priced hotel in Manhattan but do not want to compromise on a comfortable stay.

My wife and I stayed in the Hilton for two nights. On W26th St. near 7th Ave. It is well located for access to lower Manhattan as well as tourist central in the 40s and 50s. The service was decent. The room was on the small size (about 12X15, not counting the closet, bath, and small space the door opened into). The size left room for only two small nights stands, the king bed, and a desk with chair. A mid-size flat screen hung on the wall. On the plus side, everything as neat and clean. As a hotel, as such, this Hilton might get a 3.5 or four, depending on the night's rate. My based rate given a Sunday night stay, senior citizen discount, advance payment and February "dead season" timing was $189 for a king-bed room. I called the hotel directly to make a reservation. Then, unlike me, I bought some upsell by the agent. I decided on a high room he offered to get a view. That took the price to $219, but what the heck, it was a post-Valentine's Day trip. I was thinking of driving in,so I asked about parking. The agent said was would be $40 a night, but added that for an extra $50 a night (taking it to $369) I could get parking and a full breakfast for two. That was not a great bargain, but it did save a bit on breakfast so I agreed. When I got to the hotel, I pulled in up front, handed by keys to the bell hop and told him I had a parking package. Off went the car. When I got to the desk, they said that the reservation was only for either parking or breakfast not both. When I wonder why I would pay a $369 package price for parking what I could have bought separately for $10 less, the clerks basically shrugged. They produced a copy of the email confirmation that did say one or the other, which as not what the reservation agent said. I protested that the pricing made no sense, and after a bit of off to see the manager, they eventually did offer the two breakfasts as well as the parking. They also noted that the parking, if separate, would be $55, not $40. Huh? Anyway, with the pricing in hand, so I thought, up to the room we went. The room was high, I guess, on the 18th floor, but the view I had paid $20 a night for was a dingy wall with windows from which others could view me if I want to let light in my room. This was not my understanding of what a view should mean. Back to the desk. They came up with another two floors, directly above the old room, which a last gave me a view of the rooftop on the adjoining building. I settled for this, and all, I thought, was well, until I goy my checkout bill. It comped the meals, but only one night of parking. Now the figure was $65 a night. Back to the desk. They had no thought of why the clerk had said on Saturday the cost was $55 a day, but did offer that the older number, $40, was for self-park, not valet park. This was new news in the fluid price structure. More grumbling by me eventually got the $65 off the bill, although the clerks gave me that "hustler: look. Another little gotcha was that the full breakfast, was not quite the full breakfast menu, but a limited selection from it on a special voucher menu. That selection was good enough, but like the rest of the offerings not was it seemed . Now maybe I should have checked the confirmation more carefully, but given the price that seem unnecessary and, besides, I had never had such a divergence between the offer and what the charges were. I can't say "do not stay" at this Hilton because, at a base of about $200 a night, the place is reasonable (but not exceptional). But put on your reading glasses to scan the small print and put on you lawyer hat to make sure that what the reservation agent says and what the hotel is offering and at what price is accurate. Generally, I have stayed in better places with less hassle for similar money and would pick somewhere else.

This a nice boutique style hotel. The location is great. It is off Seventh Avenuie which is convenient for shopping and restaurants. Also close to the Chelsea Market, meat packing district for clubs and restaurants..
user_name:
Romargent
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed in this hotel on business for 3 nights. After a long day of meetings on my 3rd day, I sat down at the bar "Rare" which I have been told has separate ownership. The bartender had very glassy eyes, a runny nose and was sneezing, coughing and talking very loudly about how loopy the medicine she was on was making her feel. This was the person serving drinks and food! I had already been at the bar for a while when I realized how bad off she was. I immediately left without being able to eat my dinner. I called the front desk to inform them. They told me she would be sent home (I didn't even have to describe her, it was obvious who it was). I flew out to Whistler to ski the next day and of course came down with the same symptoms the bartender complained of (and lost my voice just as she was). I realize there is no guarantee that it came from her, but it ruined my ski vacation. I e-mailed Hilton to let them know what occurred. the logic was that given the horrible germ season, the hotel could remind the employees not to come to work sick. I got an e-mail back from "Wanda" that said the hotel would contact me within 3 days. They never did and Wanda hasn't responded to my follow-up email. This tells me the hotel does not take health safety complaints seriously.

I've traveled around the world enough to know you pay for what you get. I've learned recently that you don't have to put a dent in your pocket to get great quality service. Too bad it took several overnight stays in New York for me to find the perfect hotel. Again, I will be honest with you when I will tell you that I truly believe you pay for what you get...but after booking rooms that have range from $350.00 to $425.00 a night I was a bit hesitant when I found the HIlton New York Fashion District and only paying $137.00 a night. I read the reviews and questioned myself over and over again. Then finally I booked it with the hotel directly. Chelsea, who helped book the reservations was friendly and had a great personality. I checked in this past Sunday to be greeted by professional staff members. Although my room was not ready at time of arrival I understood it was only 11am and may have to wait until 3pm to do so. They stored my luggage and off I went to hit the town. The location is perfect for those who want to do Uptown or Downtown. It's close to the subway and a skip and a hop from 34th Street. Finally, I received the call around 3pm that my room was ready...Whaalla! I opened the door to room 211 and was very suprised. Not only was the room equipped with a MP3 player, Keurig, large flat screen mounted on the wall but also had all the ammeneties that you would need to make your overnight stay comfortable. Overall, if you are looking for a great, clean hotel that is going to leave your pocket full then choose this Hilton property where you will find the staff pleasant but also very eager to help you in any way. This will be the one any only hotel I will stay at for furture trips to NYC.

I had a three week stay at this hotel post Hurricane Sandy and into the beginning of the holiday season. Just as reference, I stayed at two other NYC hotels within the following month, neither of which could hold a candle to this place.This is a fairly small hotel by New York standards and had a boutique feel to it. The lobby is fairly small but hip, fashionable and sophisticated. Front desk staff was extremely accommodating, friendly and helpful.Perfect location. Away from, but within reasonable distance to, the theater district and touristy and bustling Times Square. Quieter and less congested. Food is less expensive than it is 12 blocks north and tons of non-touristy dining options. Starbucks around the corner. One block to the subway. Whole Foods a block and a half away. Greenwich Village and SoHo close enough to walk. I loved my room! Killer view of the Empire State building from the floor to ceiling windows. Modern elegance with a large desk, ample storage and a good size, well appointed bathroom. The room was small, but also a good size for New York. The bed was extremely comfy and the pillows were rockin' perfection. Large screen TV. Large granite shower (no bathtub) and decadent, fluffy white towels. Great lighting in both the room and the bathroom. Keurig coffee maker. Real glass glasses, not plastic. The perfect cocoon in a huge and busy city. Upstairs bar/lounge is nice with great views. Non-hotel guests to the bar are taken up a separate elevator to maximize guests safety. Guest access to other floors is prevented by use of a system by which you need your room key to press a floor button. I appreciated the thought given to safety.Downsides?? Not anything earth shattering. The top guest floor can sometimes be noisy from the bar above. I had only three days of late night noise/music as I was just under the lounge. But most of the time was fine.  I would hate to have booked this hotel just to get a room on the back side. The front side upper floors has the great view. I fell asleep every night to the ever changing colors of the Empire State building. There are no ice machines on the floors. However, one call to room service and they bring it to you, no charge. If you want a small fridge, just ask the front desk and they'll bring one..also no charge.I look forward to the opportunity to stay here again. This truly was a home away from home and I would completely recommend it to anyone!

spent the weekend, staff was very friendly and helpful, room was clean, comfortable, with a beautiful view of the empire state building. the location was just right for me, with subway stations two avenue blocks away, but that really depends on where you want to go in nyc. i was a little put off by the fact there was no free wifi (i guess if it says theres wifi, it doesnt necessarily mean its free, but thats what i would expect in a forward looking hotel) and the $12 they charged for roomservice tea i needed for my cough. also, who slips the bill under the door at 3am? sounded like someone trying to get in. but all this didnt really ruin my impression, which was very good.

We stayed at the Hilton, Fashion District, on our trip to NYC, to take in the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this year (2013). The staff was extremely friendly and helpful and the rooms were clean and quite comfortable. The only thing we found a bit odd was that the bathroom light comes on automatically and remains on for quite a while - perhaps an energy saving item; however, given how long it stays on, I'm not sure of the savings!The staff had freshly popped popcorn in the lobby on the Saturday afternoon that we checked in and the hotel was convenient to the Fashion Institute of Technology (we popped in to see the Shoe Obsession exhibit) and to Madison Square Garden (where the Westminster Dog Show evening events were held).We did have lunch in the hotel restaurant - Rare - however, it was not really overly impressive.We stayed on an upper floor of the hotel and it was generally quiet except for the loud door closing across the hall - not sure if this was a function of hotel acoustics or hotel guest behaviour.

It is quite hard to find a reasonably priced hotel in NYC. I tried this Hilton after having mediocre experiences at several other "mid-priced" alternatives.The location is OK but it is neither in mid-twon or Soho. It is in between most of the things you want to see as a tourist. The lobby is sort of fashionable in a way that will last at most five years. The rest of the hotel has nothing that could be remotely called fashionable.The roof top bar is packed and requires you to pass by a bouncer in the lobby. It must be thought to be very good but is hard to see why. i ordered food and gave up after 30 minutes. There was no where to sit within fifteen minutes of its opening.

This place is new to me, I decided to stay there because it is pretty close to my office. I was pleasantly surprised at how hip, yet nice the place was. They were very busy because of the NY fashion week. I found the hotel to be clean, staff to be courteous, and restaurants to be above par. I would definitely stay here again when in NY. Also, the price was amazing through Hilton website but you need to book far in advance.

When you enter, the lobby is not large, however comfortable and it is a boutique hotel feeling. . The service was great, the beds were comfortable and the morning breakfast was nice. The hotel is a short cab ride to great dining options. Only $8.50 taxi ride to theater district or Times Square. We enjoyed our stay and would stay again

We arrived just before 12 noon, friendly and welcoming reception staff had no problem with checking us in early, and as an added bonus we were given an upgrade to a two bedded room on a higher floor. The room was well furnished, with contemporary decor and a good bathroom - the shower was powerful and quick to warm.The hotel is situated in the perfect location - with several different subway lines and penn station only a few blocks away you can reach anywhere in the city quickly - and the local area, as you would expect, has a myriad of excellent restaurants and bars.Compliments are also due to the staff who were fantastic - nothing was a problem for them and they were some of the most welcoming employees of any hotel i've been to.Only negatives were the fact that the charge for wi-fi was $14.95 for 24 hrs (why do big chains get away with this when so many smaller hotels have no problem with free wi-fi?) and the fact that the lifts seemed to be in a permanent state of nervous breakdown and never displayed any of the floors correctly.

I have stayed at this hotel many times for business as it is around the corner from my NY office. This is one of the best hotels for the price in this area. I consider this one of the bangs for your buck in NY. It's close to Macy's, MSG, Times Square, the Flat Iron, the fashion district, and countless other things to see and do.The hotel has a little fashion theme to it. The front desk staff is very courteous and willing to accommodate. If you arrive on Sunday they give you a glass of champagne when you check in, which I think is a cute touch. Don't bother valet parking the car with the hotel. There are A LOT of garages around the block that are much less money. My only complaint (which is true for all Hilton Hotels) is that they charge you for WiFi.The rooms are clean and laid out pretty well, they provide a decent amount of storage (for NYC this is great) and they're quiet. They're not huge, but I challenge you to find a room in New York City for under $500 a night that is. They have nice clean updated bathrooms. Some rooms on the front of the building have a nice view, but all the others overlook an alley and other buildings.For dining options, the hotel has a great reastaurant called RARE in the lobby, and a FABULOUS roof deck when it's warm out. And in recent years there have been some great additions restaurant and Nightlife wise. Restaurant options in the area I could recommend would be Mario Batali's Eataly, Pipa Tapas Bar, and Cipriani. And after dinner I would highly recommend the roofdeck of the hotel if it's warm out, Maysville is a really cool whiskey bar, and Toshi's lounge has life music which is REALLY entertaining.Overall, if you are visiting this area I highly recommend staying at the Hilton.

This is my first visit to New York and chose a Hilton as I have always been pleased with the standard. This hotel is in the right location for my needs and I chose an upper level room so I could enjoy the view. That is good as I look up to the Empire State Building. The staff are friendly.The down points are that the daily room servicing is poor. It has been after 4 pm every day before the maid arrives. Not good if you want a break in the afternoon. There is no bath only a shower. There is a coffee maker that uses pods but there is no kettle so you are scuppered if you want boiling water for a soup or chocolate. There are no proper mugs in the room only large disposable cupsThe bed has seen better days in that someone has either been over amorous or a completely overweight has been in it. Mentioned this to the maid who simply shrugged her shoulders.Overall this is a budget hotel with a few extra bells and whistles
user_name:
Robert M
Coulsdon, null, United Kingdom

review_body: Stayed at this hotel 8 nights and it was fantastic.When we arrived at the front desk they were very nice and attentive and let us choose between 1 room at the 6th floor (to the front) and 1 room at the 9th floor (we were told that the 6th floor would be more noisy, but we choose the 6th floor, and it was fine, we heard some noise early in the mornings, but slept very well). The room (queen bed) was nice, very comfortable and looked bigger than in the photos. The bed (mattresses) was really good.The bathroom was large and the shower had good pressure.The room has a coffee machine and coffees and teas, which was a really good thing.This hotel is between the 6th and the 7th avenues (closer to the 7th), and it has near a lot of subways.The hotel area was really nice and had a lot of interesting things and spots to go (to shop, to eat, to meet).We definitively would stay here again.The concierge and the front desk were always attentive to us.

Stayed here last week for a week and price was $165 per night. Overall a satisfactory experience. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Reception staff was efficient and welcoming. Concierge was nice as were the bellhops. The restaurant staff were absolutely darling. Hostess was helpful when I went asking for take out bags (I wasn't even eating at the grill restaurant), and the breakfast waiters was very freindly. Hotel maids were very nice and friendly too.Hotel is a bit old and rooms are small, but it's NYC and space is limited everywhere. Bed was comfortable with good linen. Good bath towels. Nice bathroom sink counter with lot of counter space for make-up and toiletries. Room decor was nice with some artful paintings. I loved that they had a nice coffee maker with complimentary Newman's Own coffees. It was quite cold in NYC and I used the coffee maker to make hot water as well as teas and coffees. Only things that can use some immediate improvement were the lightings. The room was very dark at nigh even with all the lights on, especially in the entrance. The bathroom light was very bright so good side is you can see what you're doing, but the light made one looks very haggard. I asked for a refridgerator and they brought me one for use during my stay.My booking came with complimentary breakfast at the Rare Grill. The breakfast menu was ok and sufficient. They also have a buffet but I think the a la carte option is better and fresher. The breakfast entree all had meat (except for the waffles and continental pastries). I'm a vegetarian and they had no problem at all making me a veggie omelet. Hotel location is awesome. Just a couple of blocks away from the 1, 2, & 3 subway stations; Duane Reade drug store, and Whole Foods. Across the street from hotel is a laundromat so if you stay for longer period you can drop off your laundry there. Lots of quick eats and delis nearby. Also a Chipotle across from the hotel. The Gigi cafe on 7th Ave nearby serves great breakfast and lunches. I would recommend this hotel.

The hotel is clean and is located close to the districts where I work when I am in NYC. Only two of the elevators worked the 5 days I was there, so with that stated it took a long time to get one. Security seems to very good. It was rather noisy outside at times. There must have been construction going on around us. It was very easy to get a cab. Of course in January it usually is.

Booked this hotel because we got an amazing price of $169 and I would definitely stay here again. We had a room facing the inner courtyard and heard absolutely no street noise. I think this is the quietest hotel I've ever stayed in in NYC. Also clean with very comfy beds (as is typical for Hilton) and a great Keurig coffee maker. Although small, the rooms were big enough for two people to move around. The location on W. 26th is convenient to midtown and downtown alike.

I had called before and arrived at 1pm. My room was ready and exactly what I had asked for: quiet, away from the lift (elevator).The staff were really impressive throughout the stay: they couldn't do enough to help and seemed very competent. This went from the Front Desk to housekeeping to the restaurant.The hotel is noisy -- mostly because the doors seem almost spring loaded. One night, I had a couple of people on my floor who were were in and out of one anothers' rooms and banged the doors even greater gusto. Why can't hotels put springs on the doors to make them close quietly? I see that Premier Inns are planning it in the UK and this will be enough to get me to stay there when I can. There are only ten or twelve rooms per floor but if you get the wrong ten people, the corridors can be noisy too. Again, there is a lot to be said for signs and noise alarms in the hallways.My only other complaints were one lift was out of order throughout my stay -- on one evening, only one lift was working, Each lift is used by room service, housekeeping and guests for the rooftop bar so it can get slow. The mini ironing board in the rooms is almost unuseable -- proper ironing boards, please! The rooms are well furnished and smart but there's nowhere to sit. The Keurig coffee machine may appeal to some but the tea it produces is quite foul; the hotel should have electric kettles available for those of us with more primitive tastes (I had to go out and buy one along with some tea bags. I left it there so they now have at least one to loan you)My view of the Empire State building was lovely, the heating was fully adjustable (it was minus 15 C outside; in most New York hotels this means boiling inside but here it was easy to get comfortable) and the bedding (complete with high quality duvet cover) was excellent. I can't say good enough things about the people.

A lot of review here indicated this was like Hilton's version of the W. It is not even remotely close. The rooms are noticeably smaller than every W hotel I've been in, the hotel really isn't geared towards the W's demographic at all.We stayed here (and booked two rooms for us and another couple) because of the W comparison and such amenities as 24-hour room service because we usually get in late. Turns out, room service is over at 11pm. The web site advertised a non-existent feature.Check-in time is 3pm. We arrived at 1pm. No problem that our room wasn't available at this time. However, it also wasn't available at 3pm, or 4:30pm either. It is entirely unacceptable to not be let up into your room at check-in time, let alone 2 hours later.Booked both rooms on my credit card, specifically told the front desk to ONLY charge incidentals to the other couple's card for their room, that both rooms remain paid for by me. The next day the other couple got their check-out invoice, with the room charged to their incidentals-only card.Trying to be a nice guy rather than going straight to Trip Advisor to post a review, I brought all of these issues up to the manager (JP) who offered just a credit on our breakfast room service. He promised an unspecified amount of points to my Hilton HHonors account. I got none.Pros - * Nice location* Bathrooms are nice, good water pressure.* Clean rooms.* Cheap price* On-site restaurant is very nice (seems too good for hotel)Cons - * Could not check-in until 2 hours after posted check-in time.* Misrepresented room service hours.* Second room had no smoke detector (ripped off wall).* Staff doesn't understand basic billing requests.* Brought up issues to management in private, shrugged off with lame comp offer.* Is nothing like W hotels.

We arrived earlier than the check in time and the staff was gracious enough to let us check in early. Even if we weren't able to check in early they told us they would hold our bags for us which is a big plus in the city. Impressed with the security of the hotel, valet parking, very clean rooms and wonderful bed plus a nice size bathroom. This has become our go-to hotel in NYC!

We stayed in the Hilton for one week. We arrived very early in the morning and they offered us a room pretty soon.Our room was large and with a tasteful decoration. First class matress, pillows and linens. The service was very good and people in the reception very friendly.The hotel has a small and croweded lobby. They have very good security mesures to get into the rooms, only guests could get in the elevator with the same card that is used to open the room door.The hotel is not in the most beutiful block of NYC but is very convinient for using public transportation.This Hilton is a good choice for its reasonable price and confort.

We stayed in this hotel over the Thanksgiving period and found it to be a great place to get our heads down after lots of shopping and sight seeing. You are only a short walk from Macys and the subway is not far, although it is a nice walk up to Times Square. The Hotel has a newish look about it and great restaurant on the side. Also close for a good night out in the meatpacking district.Ps - also good tv channels to watch while getting ready :)

Stayed here for a short trip to New York. Central location and great rate made it perfect. Reception was very friendly. Room was very clean. Only negative was you had to wait for security to use the elevator, a new access control system is being implemented.

I loved this property. From the decor, to the finishings and furnishings, to the friendly staff and great location, it all came together wonderfully during a last-minute business trip. The property also has a great roof-top lounge and a very decent steakhouse (RARE) on the ground floor, which made late work days a lot less stressful!I usually stay at the Millennium Hilton at the World Trade Center site, but I have to say that this property offered a much more convenient place to stay - allowing more walking access to neighborhoods, and easier cabs at night (NYC cabs tend to abandon the Financial District late at night!).Little niceties for Hilton HHonors VIP members included a welcome treat of wine and snacks at check-in and bottled water.The biggest drawbacks would be the tiny rooms (even for NYC) and the views, which, due to the property's location, unless you were on the highest floors as I was, would be of more buildings, and even the offices next door were "in your face" as the building is set back from the sidewalk. From my room I had an excellent view of the Empire State Building and the Garment District.

When we arrived to the hilton this past weekend in NYC, we thought that the property was going to be awesome since they give you 24 hr room service, and they had great reviews of the hotel. We were surely mistaken when we arrived. First we had to wait until check-in time, totally reasonable since we arrived 1 1/2 hrs early. However, when the check-in time came around we were still unable to check-in someone was still in one of the rooms, and they were still cleaning the other room, mind you at check-in time they are still cleaning when check out is at 12pm and check-in is at 3pm. We said okay fine just let us know when the rooms are available. We were expecting at 6:00 we would be getting a call from the hotels that the rooms were all set and ready to be checked it. To me, this is ridiculous waiting 3 extra hours when they should have already been all set. Next we get to our rooms one of them smells like smoke. It is a non-smoking hotel know we knew why they had to have "extra" time to clean one of the rooms. It smelled pretty gross for someone who doesn't smoke. When we look at the menu to make sure room service was 24hrs, the staff had no idea what we were talking about. We thought it was our mistake looked on the website and it clearly states 24hr room service provided. The only thing nice about this hotel is the resturant next door called Rare. They have pretty good food and good drinks. I would not recommend anyone to go to this hotel even if it was for a weekend like we did. Horrible.

Stayed on 1/14/13. Pleasantly surprised with the free red wine served at check in with little goody bag of treats. I learned there was a catch - but more of that in a bit. This property is very trendy - one of the most interesting branding designs I've seen in a HIlton property. The vibe was hip and groovy but not in an rude or unapproachable way. Reserved through Hilton.com for the best price - about $30 less than nearby properties. Well worth the $199.The check in staff were great - I did receive 2 bottles of free water as a HHonors member at check in. Unfortunately I had an early flight and couldn't take up the offer for a free breakfast voucher. I regret not going immediately up to the rooftop bar to check it out - and I ended up being out too late to see it that night. But I imagine that if its anything like the rest of the property, it's a great hang out spot.After check in, the fun started. The elevators were haywire. Unfortunately, a staff member with service key, was running the elevators manually, old school. To get a lift back down from your room, you had to call down to the front desk for a lift. Inconvenient. But the staff were in such positive spirits through this, probably huge pain, that it wasn't a problem.Had a great burger with belgian style fries and drinks at the adjoining restaurant, Rare. Probably one of the top 5 burgers I've had.Check out at 5am the next day was fine - as was the valet elevator services from the 21st floor. The doorman had to run out to 7th Ave to Flag a cab for me, but it all worked out fine.Overall, an excellent stay due to the great staff and neat digs of this unique HIlton.

I was in New York for a week-long business meeting. Our offices were very close hence Hilton Fashion District was the most logical choice from a distance point of view. So that is its main (if not its only) saving grace, in my view. The service was below expectations for a Hilton hotel (i.e. I'm not asking for rose petals or ostrich-feather fans. This is not a luxury hotel and I'm on a business trip.) I was expecting at least competent staff with enough knowledge to execute basic transactions like dealing with an extension request or explaining differences between rooms. The staff handling the request couldn't wrap her head around what was going on with my booking and with those requests. At some point, she referred to her colleague who was equally lost. I just came from a 16 hour flight and didn't want to prolong standing at the reception while dealing with staff who obviously didn't know what was going on. I gave them time to sort it out till the following morning. Unfortunately, it was the same banana the next day. That sort of experience upon arrival leaves a bad taste in your mouth and makes one more critical of the hotel you're in. I was annoyed that the room they gave me was on a lower floor, looking out to a busy street - thank you for all the traffic noise - just what a jet-lagged person needs. I just didn't have the energy to deal with the staff again for a change room request. The walls on the hall were a sick shade of green that reminded me of a hospital or a low-end hostel. I could barely wait to get out each morning so instead of staying to have my breakfast there, I would dash out to grab something at the corner Argo Tea place.Overall, Hilton Fashion District was adequate accommodation for someone travelling by herself with no romanticized agendas and just expecting pure utility. It provided a bed to sleep in at a location that suited the purpose at that time. Unfortunately, nothing more.

Its completely untrue that all NY city hotels in Manhattan are expensive and overpriced. In fact, I just stayed at his lovely NY hotel for less than I paid at the Denver airport the same week. I know its a well-known fact that staying in NY is expensive and its not cheap but, you can get a good night's sleep in a clean room, just a short cab ride from Time Square and not break the bank. I would say that when returning to NY again, I would definitely stay at the NY Hilton on 26th Street and 7th Ave. Everyone was totally helpful from the front desk to the doorman.Also had their daily lunch special for only $10.95 and used my Gold status to get a free buffet in morning with fabulous fresh OJ and some of the best coffee you have ever had. I am not sure I have had a better deal than this in a long time and it was in all places NY.
user_name:
Stephen B
Corona del Mar, California

review_body: My sister and I stayed here for 4 days whilst exploring New York. ROOMSWe had a double room which was on the small side, although this is typical of New York and our window faced directly into the hotel/apartment building across the street. Although we had sufficient shutters to maintain our privacy.FOODThis was the best part...the restaurant downstairs and the rooftop bar are amazing. I would highly recommend the baby back ribs and the platters are HUGE so it wouldn't hurt to share a starter and a main and the staff were so friendly and welcomingLOCATIONI couldn't ask for a better location. It was within 10 minute walking distance to Times Square and all the sights but far enough to be away from all the major hustle and bustle.I would definitely stay here again next time I go to New York. Highly recommended.

This is a solid mid-priced hotel in a great location in Chelsea. Convenient to downtown, midtown, just about anywhere. I've stayed at this hotel about 5-6 times in the past year and it's become my go-to in NYC. It's a stealth little hotel -- even cab drivers are surprised when I tell them the address and say it's the Hilton. Everyone says "there's a Hilton there?" It used to be an independent hotel called the Fashion26 and most people don't know it changed to Hilton a few years ago.The hotel is modern, clean, and just good all around. The only drawback is that the rooms are pretty small. I expect that in NYC, so it's not that big a deal. But the room is very functional and the bathroom is new/modern and very good. Beds are comfortable, internet seems to be consistently fast, and service is pretty good.My biggest complaint is as a Hilton Hhonors Gold member, I don't seem to get an upgraded room very often. Usually the front desk doesn't even acknowledge that I'm entitled to an upgrade -- even if an upgrade isn't available, I wish the front desk would just tell me that. Instead, I go to my assigned room and it's always a mystery what I'm getting, and I'm usually disappointed. The upgraded room, when you get one, is only a little big larger than the standard, but that makes a big difference when the rooms are so small to begin with. I also tend to end up on a low floor -- usually the highest I get is floor 12 and I think there are something like 25 floors in the hotel. I'm not sure who all those people are getting high floor rooms if a Gold member like myself isn't getting one. One time I did have something on a high floor and it had incredible views of the Empire State Building. Here's hoping I get one again someday.Despite the upgrade issue, I still usually stay at this Hilton because it's good in so many other areas and the rate is usually pretty reasonable. I recommend trying it out if you haven't stayed there -- definitely better than the Four Points Sheraton a couple of blocks away and better than the Hampton and Hilton Garden Inns I've stayed at in the general area. I used to stay mostly at the Doubletree in Chelsea, but when I discovered this Hilton for about the same price, I've never looked back.
user_name:
sfguy24
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My sister and I stayed one night at the Hilton fashion district while we were guests on the Rachael Ray Show. The hotel was not aware of us being on the show, yet the staff treated us like special guests. They were friendly, accomodating, and went out of their way to make us feel welcome! The rooms were very clean and comfortable. Will definitely stay again, when we can make better use of the location and fit in some sight seeing!!
user_name:
RachaelK266
West Jordan, Utah, United States

review_body: This hotel was very nice. The rooms are very clean, and cleaned regulary. The location is very good, as its close to the empire state building, and 20 minutes walk from times square. We actually walked everywhere from here, to times square, central park, and the other way down to Ground Zero and back. The only thing letting the hotel down was the elevators, as they kept breaking down and took ages to arrive at the lobby.

Short walk from Penn Station and subway. Usually one of the least expensive among comparable hotels. Staff very friendly and accomodated an early check in more than once. Clean. Fairly quiet for Manhattan, and only small number of rooms per floor so not much hallway noise. Everytime I have checked in there has been a complimentary something at the front desk (small pastry, cookie, popcorn, interesting juice, etc). Internet free (at least for Diamond members). Stayed most recently in January 2013, have stayed several times in past. I spend about 150 nights per year away from home and this has become one of my NYC go-to hotels.

We stayed at the Hilton fashion district for 8 nights in December and overall it was a really good choice.Location: Location is really good, metro is 3 minutes walking, Penn station is 10 minutes away and is in a walkable distance of many places. There are many cafes near the hotel, where you can have breakfast in a much better price compared to the hotel's breakfast.Rooms: Rooms were nice, not really big and they provide the needed amenities. The cleaning could be a bit more detailed. Our room was at the 22nd floor and we had a really nice view making our staying there more enjoyable.Staff: I did not feel very welcoming from the staff. If you asked them anything they were providing us with information, but I did not find them really polite and helpful.Internet: The internet is charged when you are in the room, but you can use the free wi-fi service at the lobby.Price: We stayed there during the Christmas period and the prices were more expensive compared to standard rates, but again they were better compared to other hotelsThe only thing that I did not like, was hotel's charging policy. During our stay, we were "charged" some amounts for things that we "may" spend at the hotel, even though we had not spent anything more than the room's price. At the checkout these amounts were dismissed from our cards, as the hotel told us, but 10 days after the credit card was still charged.

A group of us stayed at the New York Fashion District just after New Year's Day to celebrate a birthday. My husband and I had our room, and our friends were on another floor. Since we were staying in the middle of Manhattan, we expected the rooms to be small and cozy, which they were; however, we did not stay in the room much. The room had drawers, a desk, two nightstands, a closet and a vertical shelf with a Keurig beverage maker. The bathroom had a sink, toilet and upright shower (no tub). Every once in a while, we heard the neighbor's door close, but overall, it was pretty quiet.HOTEL SERVICE - The room was kept pretty clean. There was one day housekeeping failed to leave us washcloths. The hotel took care of this right away and provided us additional washcloths and Hilton points. The bar staff at RARE was very nice and always attentive. The hotel concierge was hit or miss with their recommendations, so I would do your sightseeing homework before hand. SUBWAY - The hotel was so conveniently located near three different subway lines, so finding a route and getting to our destination, whether uptown or downtown, was not a problem at all.TAXIS - Some of the taxi drivers didn't want to drive right up to the hotel because it was located in the middle of a city block. Once again, not a problem. We paid less on the meter, and it was nice to walk. If I traveled to NYC again, I would return to this hotel.

Loved the hotel. The hotel had exceeded my expectation for the price I was paying for! Lots of space, everything was clean, front desk was friendly. There was a Keurig in the room with Peter Thomas Roth toiletries! Hotel was far from times square, but easily accessible through the metro, which the metro was also close by! I had no problem with the location because it was nice to be away from the busy times square and other tourist craziness when you want to relax in your hotel room. I did not notice a safe deposit box. Heater and AC worked well. Huge Flat screen TV. Plenty of space and long desk to do whatever desk work you need to do. Had no problem with noise and sleep :)

Everything is great, except I don't like my room being too hot. A comfortable 65 at night is good; however the room was in the 70s and there was no way to cool the room during winter months except for barely cracking the room window. I was not able to sleep so beware if you are like me and like more control of your comfort.

Stayed here for 5 nights in November for my wife's 30th. First day had to ask for the room to be made up which was disappointing. Compared with other hotels they lack the star quality of the service. Didnt find tthe concierge particularly helpful and she seemed to be more interested in shopping on the internet than advising and helping. Nice touch is the business centre but disappointing that wireless isnt free in the rooms.

Ok. The room is really small. But since this is Manhattan, I think it totally reasonable. I got there very early, and had to wait about 2 hours for a room. The waiting time was way shorter than expected. The front desk staff was friendly and helpful. I liked the scent of the hotel generally and the room. It really is a great place for rest. What I didn't enjoy so much was the window facing another building. My room was 715, and there wasn't any view. I had to pull down the shadow ALL THE TIME when I was in the room. So please take a higher floor room if possible. Since I checked in early, I guess I didn't have an option. The elevator was another issue. It does not sense your key very well. It's annoying especially if you live on a lower floor. You don't have enough time to make it work before the elevator is already on 20th floor. It just sucks. The hotel itself is new and trendy. But I'll probably stay at a hotel in more convenient blocks (7 Ave-26th St isn't) or Jersey City, where rooms are much bigger. But if you get a reasonable rate, this Hilton can be a good option.

We stayed here for 5 days during December. We got a good rate for that time of year and the hotel did not disappoint. There was a subway stop two block away and it was fairly centrally located. The rooms were small but clean and the service was great. Our TV didn't work but as soon as we called about it, it was fixed when we returned from dinner. The rooms were very quiet and since this is not a main street - there was no street noise late at night that we have expereinced in other NY hotels. The staff was very helpful in arranging transportation to the airport and storing our luggage for our evening departure. I would stay here again.

The rooms/beds were clean, they were spacious (I know, in NY) the bathroom products were great, and the staff was very friendly. The location is not my favorite, but it was close to the Javitz center, so that was all I needed. All in all, a good experience.

Just outside Times Square but walking distance to the shows.Trendy hotel, good value for NYC.Basic but nice room, comfortable bed , quiet. concierge was helpful.Work out room very basic.Would definitely stay there again.

The hotel had clean rooms, friendly people, and was very convenient to everything in the city I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to New York City. The rooftop bar was AMAZING!!!! Drinks were overpriced though. I would highly recommend giving one free drink to guests.

The hotel was great from the minute we arrived. The location was perfect for walking around New York with its close proximity to major attractions. Our room was extremely clean and well kept. The hotel was very modern and had a great vibe. I would definitely stay here again and recommend it to anyone looking for a great vacation.

I know we were staying a city that never sleeps, but our room on one of the lower floors at the front of this hotel was very noisy, all night. We heard linen and rubbish carts being rolled out and delivery trucks and removal trucks, coming and going all night.If you want to stay here be prepared for noise, paying for breakfast and waiting twenty minutes for it once ordered, wifi only in the lobby and coffee machines that don't have real coffee or real cups, only take away containers.Very disappointing and expensive, apart from the location of the hotel and the friendly staff at the front desk and bar. The concierge was also very helpful and helped us find and book tickets to see a play, but apart from the people, the hotel has nothing more going for it.we went u to the rooftop bar, which is mostly closed in and does not offer very good views of the city, despite the promises on the website. It also smelt very musty and "closed in" up there, as if it hadn't been cleaned properly for a while.

We have just arrived back in Australia after spending 13 nights in this hotel. We were lucky enough to have a room on the 21st floor which had a spectacular view of the Empire State Building. The hotel was in a great location, easy walk to a few different subway stations as well as Penn Station (for our trip to Metlife Stadium) and Madison Square Garden.From the minute we arrived to our (very sad) departure the staff were always helpful & friendly. The room was plenty big enough in our opinion and the Keurig coffee machine in our room was a lovely touch. We used it every day and thought it tasted better than the coffee in the restaurant.Breakfast was included with our room and there was always plenty of options. A special thank you to Kathy on the front desk for helping make our stay extra special. We will definitely stay here again when back in New York.There are only 3 lifts for guests and on some nights one of those is designated to getting people up and down from the rooftop bar. You may need to call for the lift a little earlier as it can get quite busy in the evening but there is nothing to be upset about, you just need to be a little more organised.May I also suggest heading upstairs to Rare View, the view really is spectacular.

We stayed at the hotel from Jan 1 to Jan 6 2013. Room was modern, good furnishing. Windows facing another building but on the other side very quiet. Check-in a little bit slow because of a lot of people checking out on that day. Excellent value for money.We had one peculiar situation: my girlfrend lost her room key. She got to the hotel and because the room was reserved on my name, when she asked for a duplicate key her name did not come up in their records. They couldn't let her in the room either, because of security issues. The people from the front desk however were very helpful, offered her food and beverages while she waited for me for about 2 hrs. When I finally came there, they even exceeded our expectations and offered us free dinner or room service apologizing for the trouble. We declined but they insisted so at the end we ordered two hamburgers and two sodas. By the way, it was great.Here comes the final remark: although they said the hotel will pay for it, returning home I found out the they charged my credit card. This is the only reason why I coudn't give them max rating.

We were very impressed with this hotel. We arrived on New Years Day for 3PM check in, however our room was not ready. The front desk staff did the best they could to resolve it as quickly as possible. They explained that as it was New Years Day, and therefore a holiday, there had been many late check outs which had put them back. We chose to wait in the lobby until the room was ready as we were tired from the flight. The staff offered to look after our bags until the room was available. We had to wait until 4.30 until a room was ready, which wasn't ideal but understandable under the circumstances. For our trouble we were upgraded, given free breakfast on our first morning and free wifi for the whole trip. We thought this was a fantastic good will gesture from the hotel and really smoothed out the rocky start. We were on the 5th floor over looking 26th street. I was woken up at 2AM by garbage vans on the first night and again at 5AM by other external noises - but that's New York! We got some ear plugs and slept soundly for the rest of the trip. On the last night we were disturbed by noisy guests in the corridor at 2AM and again at 4AM, but this was down to inconsiderate guests and not the fault of the hotel. On our first morning we ate breakfast in the hotel and the standard of the meal was excellent. Great portions and really tasty food. The location of the hotel is also really handy for getting round Manhattan. We like to explore on foot and we were able to walk to most places. We only got the subway a couple of times, and the station was really close to the hotel. On previous trips we've stayed in the theatre district which can be a bit full on. The location of this hotel is perfect if you want to relax into New York life. There are plenty of bars, restaurants, cafes and delis in very close proximity. We liked Sunac deli, which is just around the corner from the hotel. We also went to the Hog Pit bar and restaurant on 26th st, which I also recommend. There is a great cinema in Chelsea called Clearview, which is a 5 minute walk from the hotel. The high line is also not far away andIi recommend the Chelsea markets - especially Eleni cookie store.Overall I would not hesitate in recommending this hotel. The cleanliness and quality of the room was great. We would stay here again in a heartbeat.

My mum and I stayed at the Hilton Fashion district in Manhattan in November 2012. For me it was my third visit to Manhattan and for my mum her first. I alway like to try new hotels, but I have to stay I will defintely come back to the Hilton. The location, the service and especially the price are just some of the selling points for me. The rooms are of a good size, and include all the neccessities, bathroom is very nice, and daily roomcleaning. There is enough room for storage. You might hear some street noice mostly trucks in the middle of the night, but that never bothered me. And there is carpetry on the floors, so if you are allergic, like me, remember to take your pills with you (i'd forgotten mine). But does are just minor points. An extra bonus was the popcorn machine and complimentary wine at the reception in the afternoon. For eating NYC is excellent, when you walk out the door and turn left and then right on 7th avenue, there 's an excellent breakfast diner, that offers everything you might be craving for (just forgot the name). And right on the corner ther's a Chipotl, oh soooo yummy Mexican food. I could go on and on. Macy's is just a few blocks away, as are the other major departments stores. One day we walked from the hotel to central park and back, which was great. Needless to say that I did loose a few pounds during my stay :-)

We stayed for a couple of night just after New Years, and found clean comfortable rooms, free internet access in the lobby, right in the middle of town, would stay there anytime. There's a rooftop bar with wonderful views. The porter guys were great, Jose could not have been more helpful.

The hotel is located on a quiet side street just below Madison Square Garden. Even though it's a Hilton the feel of the hotel is more boutique than mass produced. The rooms are of good size and the furnishings extremely comfortable. The front desk staff are very professional and friendly. My wife and I enjoyed a lovely weekend stay. BTW there's a terrific wine shop just across the street (Burgundy Wine Company) and a less expensive parking garage less than a block away.

This is a great place to stay in NYC. Excellent value for money, especially for NYC. It is located about 5 minutes walk from the subway, an easy 10 minute walk from Madison Square Garden, about a 10 minute subway ride from Times Square and yet is still very quiet at night time. Rooms are good all though we felt quite poorly lit. I would definitely stay here again.

Having moved from another Hilton hotel due to issues with the hotel services and rooms, I must say that even though I was not expecting much, this Hilton hotel was a pleasant surprise. We stayed for 4 nights over the New Years period.The room, albeit small, was nice and modern. It would have been good to get a larger room for 2 twin beds but we were willing to live with it because we had just come from awful experience at another Hilton Hotel down the road. We booked a twin room on a high floor, but this did not really provide a view. Just a view into some offices across from the hotel. So I don't think I will be spending more for a high floor next time.The location is great. Close to Penn Station, Macy's and Times Square. There are also some subway stations close by so you can get around Manhattan pretty easily.The staff (front desk, conceirge and restaurant) were great. Very helpful.As an HHonors Gold member we got free breakfast which was excellent.Another small thing to complain about is the the cleaning was not always up to scratch. You could tell that there were different cleaners on different days. Some who did a great job and other who just "tidied up". But this was not a train smash as the beds were always made and the bathroom (most importantly) was adequately cleaned. On the whole, we were much happier here and I will definately be back.

The Positives:Finding a hotel in Manhattan over New Years was never going to be an exercise in value for money. With Time Square but 20 minutes walk away, the city becomes a mega-magnet for visitors at this time of the year and accordingly prices seem to match the heights of the skyline for which NYC is so famous.However, price aside, the Hilton Fashion District Hotel was a good location. We arrived in NYC by Amtrak from Washington at Penn Station and the hotel was but a convenient 10 minute walk with suitcases (on wheels).The hotel room was a little cramped but this was partially due to the number of suitcases that we were travelling with. Essentially, it was central to most activities to which we engaged ourselves during our 3 night stay.The Negatives:Unfortunately, we had a negative encounter with the hotel housekeeping at the Hilton Fashion District of a type we have never experienced anywhere else in the world. My wife went to make a coffee on our second evening in the hotel and discovered to her disgust that the housekeeping staff had given us (disposable) cups that had obviously already been used.
