I expect to see electric baseboard heaters in the bathroom of a 1 or 2 star hotel, not in a Hilton. Bed was comfortable but didn't do much good, as sound insulation from the street and hallway is terrible. Heard the sanitation trucks at 4AM and people talking in the hall at 5AM. Shower door does not properly seal in water so I was faced with a pool of water on the bathroom floor. No turn down service so wet towels stayed on the floor. It's not just me - spoke with a woman in the elevator who was so unhappy she was changing hotels.

We came home with bedbugs after staying here one night. We live in a single family dwelling and had never seen these before. A quick Google revealed that these are the bugs we saw in our room and had begun to hatch out on our mattress on several locations. When we called management, they didn't bother to check and said that we couldn't prove it. The timing of the infestation and fact that we didn't stay anywhere else confirmed. Also, I left my bags and clothing on the floor and then placed it by my bed at home. Don't take your chances. These are horrible and we are still battling the pests.

This hotel had great reviews, and they were spot on! The hotel was in the perfect location. We walked almost everywhere from here. We took the subway a couple times, station is so close. The rooms were small, but all are in NYC. They had Keurig coffee machines, very fun. The bed was great. I have Gold status, so breakfast was included. It may have been the best breakfast I've ever had at a hotel! The options were endless. That is all we ate here, there is so much good food in NYC. There is a CVS nearby for snacks or anything else you forget. We did grab a drink at Rare when we got back the first night. It was fun, great view of the city. The service was very nice, the front desk very accommodating. The room was very clean, and modern as well. I would stay here again!

Room was clean, not large but adequate. We had a twin room on the 15th floor which was quiet and we got sleep on every night. There was some noise from the door going to the fire escape and stairs but generally it was very peaceful.The staff were polite and very helpful. The toilet seat was broken when we arrived but maintenance were very prompt and came to replace it immediately.The housekeeping team were satisfactory and did tidy and clean the room every day as you would expect though it was usually quite late in the afternoon.There is not very much storage in the bedroom though and we had no where to leave our cases. Also there was only one chair so we ended up sitting on our beds instead. Not a big deal but means that it felt a bit cramped at times.

Yes, the hotel is a Hilton, but no it is not the standard large hotel with all the amenities.It does have a restaurant and a roof top bar, but not have an inhouse spa and pool. For any one looking for a smaller hotel with a little bit of style and an excellent location in the heart of Chelsea, this is a great find. The hotel is located just 3 blocks from the main shopping street - 23rd Street with Eataly Italian food Emporium by Madison Square Park in one end the High Line garden in the other. Subway lines 1, C and E stops within blocks of the hotel and the hotel is one of the newer smaller hotels that offer a circular drive way for easy unloading and loading. My room was small but included a large comfortable bed and all things required for an comfortable stay. Arriving at 9am, my room was not available as expected. I spoke with Caroline at front desk who made sure I received a quiet room that I wished for and she even called me on my cellphone when the room was avialable (2pm).I will be returning.

The hotel sits in an unassuming area however it is a very short (7 min.) walk to Penn Station. The rooms are clean and neat, the bathrooms are upscale with everything in working order. We traveled with another couple and their room was the same quality. In relation to other boutique hotels in Chelsea, such as the Eventi, this one is not as posh, a little more austere than you would expect a 4 star to be. But we bid a reduced rate on Priceline so for what we paid we can't complain!

The room was clean, modern, but very small. We had a Queen bed on higher floor. Bathroom was nice but glass doors. The door closest to shower head is actually a glass wall, so you can't turn on the shower without getting in. Close to subway. Whole Foods around the corner which we got dinner at one night and brought back to hotel. Walking distance to Eataly if you want to give that a try. Close to Shake Shack too. We were by elevators but didn't have any noise issues. No pets allowed at hotel. Rooftop bar but didn't get to see. Restaurant was pretty good for an easy close by location.

I stayed here in July 2011. I went to NYC for 10 days on business and also got in quite a bit of sightseeing as well. It is a modern, clean, comfortable hotel. I loved the location. It was my first time to NYC so I didn't know what to expect, but after a day I managed to figure out the subway system and everything was great. It is a couple of blocks from the 1 train which will take you to quite a few tourist places in NYC. It's also walking distance to many attractions like Times Square, Soho, Broadway, etc. It was a great base for my time in NYC and would not hesitate to stay here again while in NYC either on business or on vacation.

Visited with my wife and two other couples. Everyone was very satisfied with our stay without any inconveniences. Rooms are small but nicely decorated and bathrooms are very nice (although the shower is not very practical). Location is close to MSG in case you watch a game at the garden (definitely recommended!!!!!!) but the area around the hotel is not the best. Rooftop bar closed very early so we didn't visit it; on the other hand the restaurant and the room service were good. Lastly, the doorman the day we left (Feb 10) was one of the best professionals I've met!!! Really sorry that I cannot recall his name!

Smaller than expected, but it's a modern, comfortable and well decorated hotel with cozy rooms and friendly staff. I made the mistake of picking one of the busiest weekends to go to NY - fashion week + 10 years of 9/11, so all the hotels available were a lot more expensive than usual. Still, worth it!

My wife and I stayed here in Feb-Mar '12 and we were so happy about our hotel experience. We rode the train in from D.C., and what's great is it's just 5 blocks from Penn Station, so we could walk. It's in the heart of the Fashion district, but within walking distance from Times Square, Broadway, Tribeca, Soho, and many other great places. The staff was great from the first minute of arriving. The room, is small, but It's huge by NYC standards. The views are great, and they bar is fantastic. It was a little loud at night, but again it's NYC. We loved it and will book here EVERY TIME we visit NYC.

I am writing this review whilst waiting for my cab back to JFK in the hotel lobby. The lobby is always very busy - porters are more interested in you if you are going to Rooftop Bar. The rooms are small here but expected in NY. I had asked previously to have a higher floor room - but when I arrived I was given a room on floor two. Customers requests, not always listened too. Again, I had agreed on check in to only charge my accommodation/tax to the card I booked with. But the morning of check out, I received my bill shoved under my door (which woke me up - too early) to see that all my other charges had been charged ALREADY to my card - this was not what I has asked, again! Room service was ok, quite rude as didn't understand my english accent and gave the phone over to someone else, without letting me know! Concierge seemed to be very bored and unhappy everyday when I was walking through the lobby. As I work in a hotel in the uk, the first thing of working with the customers is 'Service with a smile'. I went to the Rooftop Bar on my last night here, and the two ladies that directed me in the lift and to the bar were very friendly, please pass my comments onto the staff. Never used the main restaurant, as always too loud, as travelling on my own, this is not what you want.

Stayed for a 3 day weekend in Feb. The hotel was very nice, the lobby a little small, staff was helpful and friendly. We upgraded to a higher floor since this was my first time in NYC, the view was awesome, the Empire State Building was unbelievable!! The rooms were nice and newly remodeled. The shower was a little strange as the shower and bathroom floor have nothing seperating them, therefor the floor got a bit soaked after showers. The rooftop bar has a wonderful view and some great drinks. Sorry to say we didn't get a change to try Rare, the resturant in the hotel, but it was packed every night so that must mean it was fun. The location of the hotel was good, walking distance to ESB, The Rock and Time Square if you are up for it. Subway not far, nice park around the block. Definately would stay here again!

Just spent 3 days in NY and stayed at the Hilton Fashion District, what a pleasant surprise. Friendly knowledgable staff, good rooms, good location.Overall my stay at the Hilton Fashion district was a very pleasant experience. My room was at the front of the hotel on level 8, the only noise disturbance was the refuse vehicles which visited between 1 and 2 a.m. every day, but after the first night even this did not disburb my sleep. Must mention the staff, whatever we asked was answered with a smile and a positive response. Reception, concierce and door staff were all helpful and well informed on local restaurants and transport. They even made time for a friendly chat.Breakfast was plentiful, although not the best (bacon was burnt but quickly replaced when we asked). If as part of your room rate you definately won't go hungry, but you will find better in the local area.The only small problem was the room heating, it pushed out hot air for a while then switched itself off, let the room temperature drop until you were cold and then boosted out hot air again. We were visiting in February and it was relatively mild, it could have been a lot colder and I cannot comment on the quality of the air-con for when the weather is warmer. Overall nothing to complain about and the location was perfect for exploring Manhatten, we were able to walk everywhere (good comfortable shoes recommended). Will definately use this hotel again.

Stayed here for three nights in February. Cannot beat the hotel's location. We stayed in a fairly cheap room so they were small. Rooms were nice and comfy for their size. Only complaint is that the hallways are noisy. The doors seem to make a lot of noise when they shut/slam from other guests. Otherwise fully recommend this hotel.

Stayed here in mid-February for two nights. Experience at hotel was quite good save for a couple of things. Even as Diamond member ended up in a room that seemed quite tight... space between beds and the wall was about 6 inches at best, which made it difficult to get to the chain used to close the blinds in the evening. No sitting chair in room, except at desk. Would have expected slightly more room or least the hotel not configuring two queens in a room most likely designed for one. Second point is the food offering at the breakfast buffet. Given that this particularly Hilton appears to attract an eclectic clientele - many Europeans and Asians - the food offerings seem to be very retrograde - heavy on cholesterol - and no healthy offerings - no fruit, no vegetables, not lean protein, and no non-white flour breads or muffins. Other Hiltons seem to offer these as many clients prefer to not to eat greasy sausages, bacon and eggs every breakfast. Perhaps a change in the morning chef might be in order. Agree with other reviewers who found the motion activated lights in bathroom annoying - particularly at night when they seem to stay for a long time - the only option is to close the door. Frig in room was loaded with payables, with NO room for any personal items. On the plus side, great location and ambiance. Great views from top floor bar - BTW: the dedicated elevator after 17:00 is for direct access to the rooftop bar. I found all of the staff very accommodating and outgoing; the concierge was very helpful in finding a shop I was seeking. Nice touch was the need to use room key to operate elevator - certainly enhanced feeling of security. Wi-fi was strong - at least in my room on the top floor. Nice touch also that window opened for fresh air. Plus also was the goodly number of outlets, particularly at bedstand – which could be used to charge phone and other things overnight.Would certainly recommend this Hilton for its location... hopefully with time, healthier buffet options may be introduced and when that happens this will be an excellent property.

This hotel was a great place to spend a long weekend in NYC. The room was clean and modern, although a bit small like all NYC hotels. I like this location, because it has just the right level of activity for me. There are lots of restaurants nearby, but the streets are not too crowded. Also the staff here were very kind and personable. I was of course happy to be offered a mini-cupcake every time I went past the front desk. Nice touch!
Enjoyed my stay. Updated modern rooms. Great Location.

The Hilton Fashion District is a relatively small hotel for a Hilton brand. It's in a great location, 6 blocks from Penn Station and right in Chelsea. Being that I spend most of my time in Chelsea- south - it was nice to be able to walk most places.The hotel staff is attentive. The lobby and rooms are modern. The lobby is very small so it's not a pleasant place to wait for your room to by ready (mine was ready at 2pm). I selected (and paid slightly more for) a high-floor room. I had a nice view of the Empire State Building but it's not worth more than $10 a night more. The rooms are small, but it is NYC, but they are comfy. King bed, large TV, nice desk space, good temperature control. There is a neat "bar" cabinet that holds the Keurig coffee maker (nice touch) and space for goodies (ie. vodka, snacks, etc.) that you may bring with you or run out and purchase. One downside that wasn't as bad as I thought was there are NO ice machines. You have to call room service. There is no charge (except tip) but I prefer to get my own ice and get it as often as I'd like. Not a huge deal but eh. The bathrooms are a nice size for NYC. With nice showers (with good shower heads) and a nice large vanity. The only other thing I did not like was they only had small table-top ironing boards in the room. They definitely could fit a regular (albeit smaller) ironing board hanging on the wall in the closet. It was very hard to iron on the bed and on the bathroom vanity (I tried both).All-in-all, this is a great hotel if you can get a decent price. I would definitely stay here again.p.s. the restaurant, Rare, that is in the hotel is VERY good - at least the cobb salad I had (and the dishes my friends had) was excellent! The menu looked super yummy and the room service menu was good too and decently priced (although I didn't partake).

I stayed at this hotel a few weeks ago and eveyrthing was going fairly normal. As a diamond member, I expect the normal amenities, but the biggest test is when things don't go normal and how they respond to it. I received contradictory information about checking out a day early. The person when I checked in said "no problem, just let us know." She did not say let us know immediately or there was a fee. It was not so much that I had a problem with the fee being charged, even though that was not what they told me. It was the rudeness that I received from the front desk staff and the manager on duty. As a diamond member, I never want to be told "that is our policy" and when I told her I would never stay there again "I will pass that on to my manager" and then hung up on. Since I doubt that she ever passed that on to her manager, I took the liberty of letting your manager know in this forum! BTW, I am not a chronic basher. This is the first time I have ever given a negative review of a hotel on a public forum. Diamond members --go elsewhere. There are pletny of better options in NYC that will truly pull out all the stops to handle your one-off situations.

I've been to New York a number of times, and each time, I often stay in the Times Square area. This time, I ventured out for a long weekend vacation with my brother and couldn't have been happier with the results. The hotel is in a great location on 26th street and 7th ave in Chelsea, near Madison Square Gardens and the fashion district, and is a short walk to Times Square, 5th avenue and Soho (great shopping areas). The staff were also very professional and helpful. The hotel itself has great rooms that are very clean, updated and comfortable. While standard rooms in NYC are on the smaller-side, I found our room and bathroom to be slightly bigger than expected, which was nice. We also got a really good deal for a room with a double bed, which is sometimes hard to find! I had read some prior reviews about noise from the rooftop lounge and the street. We stayed on the 20th floor at the back of the hotel. While we didn't have the best view, it was a nice, quiet stay for us and we were high enough that we didn't look into the windows of the office buildings behind the hotel. For a great view of the city, especially the Empire State Building, I would recommend heading to the hotel's rooftop lounge, RARE. Cocktails are pricey though starting at $14 each, but the ambiance is nice. All in all, I would definitely stay here again and would recommend it to anyone looking to stay somewhere central, but away from all of the tourist hustle and bustle of Times Square.

Got a deal on a room, but would have stayed here for more than I paid and will stay here again on my next trip in June. Location is spot on, much to do surrounding it, subway less than 2.5 blocks away (A,C,E), and an easy walk to Times Square, etc. This is a bustling neighborhood and quite central. You'd be hard pressed to get better for the location and proximity to everything. The room is quite large (after reading reviews here, I was prepared to be in a cage) with all amenities (iron & board, flat screen tv, desk, AWESOME shower/bathroom, complimentary gourmet coffee maker, mini-bar), however as some have noted, no fridge. I would have liked that, as I like to keep some juice, water, breakfast items on hand, but no biggie (there is a Whole Foods 1 block away, so I went and bought as I needed). I was on the 10th floor, street facing, on a weekday and weekend nights, no noise problems at all. Bedding and towels were top notch. Service at desk was great, had umbrellas when I asked on the one drizzly night. Very friendly there. Check in and out was a breeze. A few 'odd' things, if they can even be called odd, but I wanted to mention. The lobby is small, was crowded in the afternoons when people were checking in, slightly difficult to navigate at these times. There are 4 elevators, but 1 of them appears to be a 'private' elevator, they often had someone holding the door, but with a slightly menacing look, implying I shouldn't even try to use it. And I saw guests being 'ushered' into that elevator at various times (is there an exclusive floor or club we don't know about that only this elevator goes to?). Some have mentioned speed of elevators, I never had an issue of more than a 30 second or so wait. They appear to have security in the lobby. Typically 2 guys. This is not a bad neighborhood, nor did I ever feel a need for these security guys to be standing right in the middle of the lobby and me having to navigate around them. That was really the most unnerving thing about my stay there. I really felt like I was being watched a bit, and that it was overkill. A little discretion, please. Needed extra blankets, had to call twice to get them to arrive. Lastly, skip the concierge. Twice, I asked about restaurants, she had no clue as to what I was asking about, didn't even know what I was asking about was a restaurant. How does a concierge of a hotel like this not know what Eleven Madison Park is? It's one of the best restaurants in the city. Very confusing for me when a guest knows more about the dining scene than the person who is suppose to be helping us navigate it. Wi-fi too expensive to buy. Overall, great experience. I give good marks, and will be back.

Myself, my partner and a group of friends visited on a long weekend to celebrate my 40th birthday. The hotel staff were very welcoming and polite. The room was extremely tidy and had views of the Empire State Building. The top floor bar had some stunning views and was a great place to spend a few hours. Food and drinks were great although a tad pricey, but you can say that for most of New York. Location was great for us and in walking distance to many well known landmarks. We all loved our stay and would definitely recommend it to anybody else thinking about visiting NYC.

I have stayed here twice and would do so again. The rooms are small (not surprising) but nice. Very comfortable beds. Lobby restaurant has pretty good food. I also love the location; Chelsea and a short walk to a few subway stations. We were able to get a discount and so it was a great value for the price.
Perfect place to stay for a shopping weekend! Staff was very helpful and friendly. Room was very clean and confortable.

stayed in the highest floor. the view to the empire state building was fantastic but here is the problem: it's right under the bar on the top floor and the music bothered me a little. the room was surprisingly large in NYC standard and was very clean. the street was not quiet until very late (2pm or so). I'd consider stay here again but not the top floor (high floor option). I also did not like the $15 a day Internet charge even tho my company paid for it.last thing: be careful when the bill boy asked you "do you want yellow cab or flat rate $65 including tip to JFK?". I took the later option and $65 was cash-only. Paid $75. I know yellow-cab also charges flat rate and it should be ~$60. kinda sneaky.

Hotel is located about 1.km from Time Square so hotel location is good. Rooms are very small but highly equiped and bed is very comfort. Hotel staff is very friendly but breakfest was very poor. I recommend this hotel for business traveller or couple who want to sleep very comfort.

This Hilton hotel is in a very convenient place for touring both midtown and the lower parts of NYC. The accommodation is more than decent, professional staff, and good breakfast. Look out for the discounts, prices change on a daily basis, and when you catch them - the price is excellent for the value.

This Hotel Is In A Great Location For People That Want To Explore NYC Or Just Want To Shop. The Lobby Is Very Nice, They Had Mannequins Dressed In Fashionable Colthing Hence It Being Called Fashion District Hotel. Don't Really Like How You Have To Use The Room Key To Work The Elevator But Not Such A Big Deal. Rooms Were Spacious £ Very Clean. Great Thermostat In The Room For Cold Nights. Love The Keurig They Provide You With £ Coffe Or Tea. Mini Bar If You Like. Nice Bathroom. Overall Great Stay, Nothing To Complain About Except When I Called The Front Desk For Toothpaste It Never Came.

I have stayed in all types of NYC hotels from high end luxury to budget basic. This hotel is a nice surprise. I stayed 5 nights during a recent business trip and found the hotel to be perfectly suitable for what I needed. First the pluses--the location can't be beat. Easy walk to Herald Square for those who love to shop, great neighborhood walking for those who like that, and quick in/out to either LGA or EWR. Several subway stops are accessible within a couple of blocks with 6th Avenue close by for cabs uptown and 7th Ave to go downtown. Whole Foods 1 block away makes up for the lack of good deli take-away on the street, but 7th Avenue has plenty of other good restaurants. I did not try the hotel restaurant but the roof top area was quite nice. The front desk staff was terrific. I had an issue with the reservation reflecting the wrong room rate and it was handled on the spot to my satisfaction. They do have luggage hold and I appreciated the security at the elevator banks making sure nobody without a room key was going up. In the guest rooms the beds are comfortable and clean and the bathroom is spacious enough to actually have a counter--often hard to find in a NYC hotel room. The shower had good pressure, the towels were thick, and everything was clean and modern. The desk area provided plenty of power access and enough surface space to make up for not having a separate dresser. There are drawers in the desk for people like me who are staying several days. End tables on both sides of the bed also had power outlets--great for charging a phone overnight and still using it as an alarm. Heat/Air in the room was reliable and efficient. The closet is small, but adequate and there is an in-room safe--a must for any NYC hotel I stay in. The CONS:Construction on the restaurant meant my 4th floor room was very loud well into the wee hours of the night. One night off-loading of scaffolding lasted until about 4 am. This was incredibly disruptive. I strongly encourage a high floor room. The room does not have a microwave or mini-fridge, which for short-stays is probably not a big deal but it would have been nice to have as I don't eat out every meal. The nearby Hilton Garden Inn does have these things and having stayed there as well for an equally long trip it gets my vote over this hotel. The decor is not my taste. Very dark and metallic. That doesn't impact anything other than personal preference. I would recommend this hotel for anyone who is traveling to NYC for business or pleasure.

We stayed here recently due to an event we had to attend that was on the same street. What a nice surprise! The hotel is so small and the service very personal. It was the first time at check-in that a Hilton employee ever greeted me as a Hilton Honors member and went over all the additional perks we were entitled to (without me having to ask). The room was beautifully decorated, bathroom updated, and we had a great view of the Empire State building glowing in blue for the Giants game that night! Our only problem was with the sensor light in the bathroom, which seemed to decide on it's own when it was going to turn off, leaving each of us in the shower in the dark! Breakfast was in their restaurant, RARE, and we had the option of a a carte or buffet. We chose the buffet. The food was good, not great, but perfectly fine. If I needed a hotel in this area of Manhattan again, I would definitely choose this one.

I've stayed at all the other Hiltons in NY and well....they are pretty standard big city hotels with little to no character. Hilton NY Fashion District was a real surprise - small but still big enough to feel like a hotel, perfect location for all parts of the city, really friendly and attentive staff (that's unique in itself for NY!), attractive mid size rooms all modern but with a real boutique feeling to them and good food to round it all off.I stayed for three nights over a weekend in between meetings and got an amazing deal which made it even better. I was made to feel at home from the moment I got there. Ate in the restaurant the first night as I was late getting in - they specialise in burgers and steaks and although this might put a few people off, it is well worth a try - the food was excellent. Also breakfast a la carte (which is included if you book with breakfast) was fantastic. There are loads of restaurants really close by - the concierge advised me to go to "Eataly" which was a really good experience - two floors of what can only be described as an "Italian market hall" serving every type of Italian food imagineable - I went to the seafood concession, sat at the counter and watched them cook mouth watering dishes.You have to go up to the rooftop bar whilst at the Hilton too - great vews of the Empire State building which is just a few blocks away. A great place to either start or finish the evening!

Where to stay in NYC? With some help from TA as well as our son and San Francisco Travel we selected one of Hilton's newest hotels. Having heard Hilton's CEO talk about their recent opening of over 170 new properties I was anxious to see what this was like and continue to grow our Hilton Honors points. This is a sleeper. Reasonably priced, convenient location between 6th Ave.and 7th Ave. on 26th St. The staff was excellent, very accommodating and friendly. The room was just what we had hoped for and our sons room which was a corner one had a very spacious sitting area. Clean, spacious for this price range and well appointed. Our room was on the 21st floor with a southern view. Quiet at night and very comfortable and cozy king size bed. The weekend we were in NY we had a snow storm and woke up to a winter wonderland in Manhattan. imagine that! We had a few meals in Rare, the hotel restaurant, and watched the Giants - 49ers game from the Roof Top Bar and the Hotel Lobby Bar, Rare. My dirty martini was perfect and the food was just right for the game. Try the Trio Sliders. We had a choice of parking or breakfast and opted to take the parking with our room for $40.00 per night. We were surprised to be given the breakfast coupons anyway and used them for the buffet breakfast 2 out of the 3 mornings we were there.This was a very pleasant stay and we will be back.

Stayed here in november and this is a good hotel with all the amenities of a modern Hilton. The rooms were nice but ours faced an office which meant they got a view of us.Bar at the top is fun and all the staff were excellent. Only downside is location as a bit too far to walk to most things touristy.

I'll make this quick. I recently stayed at this Hilton for business. The hotel staff was attentive, the entire building and all rooms felt up to date, and the location was great (near a lot of subway stops AND near a lot of restaurants/banks/coffee/etc). I stayed in a Queen room- it was a fairly small room-- would have been two small if there were too people in the room.The hotel has the feel/vibe of a W hotel.Best part- the complimentary toiletries are Peter Thomas Roth. Very nice.The reason I only gave 4 stars instead of 5: room was tight, tv only had a few stations and I heard a lot of noise from the street below. Also, it was annoying because anytime you wanted to use the elevator (even to leave your room and go down to the lobby) you had to swipe your room card.But, again, the room was a great value for the price.

Great location, parking a block away from property. If you don't use valet, leave the bags in the Hotel and park. Efficient front desk and helpful service all over hotel. Small rooms and very small shower cabins, considering that we had upgrade, I can not imagine how small are other rooms. Room was clean and looked new. Breakfast was on a modest side and buffet option was available, but was not attractive. We stay in the Hilton Hotels all the time and were surprised with the modesty of breakfast options.Restaurant decorations are based on barb-wire pictures and if you were never in prison you can get that feeling of the first visit, enjoy. Overall, good property and service, but no trills.
Great new hotel between Broadway and 6th. Have stayed here a few times and have always had a good experience. I would definitely stay here again.
Nothing special, small rooms, lousy breakfast. I can not recommend
Love this hotel. I've stayed a few times for business and always been pleasantly surprised by the consistent service and overall experience. Great location, not touristy and nice sized rooms.

As we had booked a 'queen bed' room, we were expecting a smallish room. However, we were pleasantly surprised! It was spacious, very clean, fashionable, had an amazingly comfortable bed and in a great location for a sightseeing holiday. The concierge was always very helpful with sightseeing queries and finding out where to go on nights out. Definitely recommend it!

I stayed here for only one night but it was perfect for my short business trip. The location is perfect, walkable from Penn Station and minutes away from a number of subway stops. My room was small, even by NYC standards, but very clean. The large—but comfy—King bed was a welcome sight when I finally crashed at 3 am. I would stay here again for the location and cleanliness. The front desk service was very good, but I was a bit disappointed when it turned out I know more about Brooklyn than the concierge—and I don't know much.

This was my 2nd time here at the Hilton, don't get me wrong it's a great small hotel, the rooms are very nice, and the size is pretty typical by New York standards, extremely quite on a high floor. As far as location goes it's close to everything, if you"re a walker. If you take cabs -Depending on what direction you're going in it's better to walk either to the corner of 7th or to the corner 6th to get a cab. They have a Roof Top bar that's open all year round, with a great view of the Empire State building. They have a restaurant called Rare, that has pretty good hamburgers too.The staff is very friendly, check in was easy, we needed extra pillows they were there in a jiffy and trust me you do need extra pillows. The complimentary shampoo, conditioner and soap are excellent quality brands.The do have valet which was great checking in, but the reason I didn't give 5 stars is because when you check out and you have to get your car, expect to wait over an hour. Which is especially frustrating when you turn in your valet ticket 20 minutes before someone else and they get their car before you. Note to this hotel - please work on the process for getting your car out of Valet, even in New York, I've never had to wait that long for my car to come up.

Stayed one night at this hotel and found it to be perfect for our needs. We were heading to Sleep No More which is a few blocks away, so great location for us. Overall, the room was pretty great. Bathroom was clean, bed was comfortable, check-in was simple. A few little missteps here and there. The room temperature was easy enough to change but the window/vent area was drafty. We got room service because we were in a rush to eat and the burger was delicous -- the can of soda, however, was $3.25. I can understand a restaurant charging up to $1.50 for a 12 oz can, but $3.25 is almost laughably steep. Finally, there is no mini-fridge, just a mini-bar/vending machine. Overall, I would definitely stay here again.

I was very happy with my stay at the Hilton New York Fashion District hotel. At night it was quiet enough to get a good night's sleep. The staff was very helpfull and friendly. I plan on returning to the hotel in the summer.

As a fan of the Hilton chain, I was ready to love this newer addition to the NYC Hilton family of hotels. If you want to be close to lots of quaint neighborhoods with tons of intriguing restaurants and shops (Chelsea, Grammercy, Murray Hill) and still within walking distance to major hubs - Penn Station, Macy's and more - then this place is a good choice. But I found the hotel a bit perplexing. Good breakfast, comfortable bed, and quiet room. Yet, it was a small hotel by Hilton standards with a sort of modern lobby with cold feel to it. The room was small even by NYC standards (not even room for a small chair), the shower was poorly designed, cabs outside were hard to find, and customer service was unimpressive. I checked in a bit early at 11:45 am. They had me wait in the small lobby for a room, informing me that within a half hour a room would be available. An hour later I asked if we had any progress with a room and they said they gave away the available rooms. Rather than miss my meetings, I told them I would check in later that night. I asked the concierge for directions to a specific address and she was unable to help me and suggested I just call the company and ask them. Would I stay here again? Yes, if the price was right. Otherwise, keep looking - there are a lot of hotels in this part of Manhattan.

Just returned from a truly fabulous stay at this Hilton property! It has a boutique hotel feel to it, which I loved.Positives:-Rooms are hip, modern, new and very clean-The property is not huge, like the awful Hilton near Times Square, so I never had to deal with lines, elevator waits, an over-crowded lobby, etc.-Beds are so clean, and comfortable – this was the best sleep I’ve had, next to my stay at the Andaz, last year in NYC-Location is good, if you are looking to not be in the midtown area – great food and stores are in walking distance or a really quick cab ride (I was able to walk to Chelsea)-Staff was helpful-Great value! The nightly rate was $40 cheaper per night than the Hilton property in Times Square - and this place is sooo much nicer, newer, quieter and cleaner!-So quiet - that is a HUGE plus for me!Negatives:-Because it isn’t a spralling hotel, there aren’t cabs lined up outside, if you are looking to grab a quick taxi. Im the mornings the bell desk was happy to hail cabs down though.

This hotel has an amazing location, within walking distance to Madison Park (and therefore to Eataly - for some superb Italian gourmet treats and Shake Shack for yummy burgers), Chelsea Market and even SoHo. Having been to NYC a few times before, my husband and I were quite amazed by the size of the room. Actually, as we were upgraded to a King room, I guess we could do the most from its 2010 renovation, which is very clear in their spacious bathrooms, with spotless tiles and everything one needs to feel comfortable, specially when you have a whole 8 nights-stay. Not to mention the nice touch provided by a Keurig machine, that makes it handy for some coffee to go in the morning.Bed was so comfy we slept late quite a few times!Only drawback is the $ 15 fee for wi-fi, charged to every single device. It really gets to my nerves that such a hotel does carry out such policies, also does not make it available to the guests in the lobby! Come on, guys, no need to be that greedy! But it didn't turn out to be a problem considering we had gotten a great deal through Expedia, which made it only $124 per night plus tax.No doubt would stay there again.

Me and my mum stayed here at the begining of September 2011. I am not normally one to feel compelled into writing reviews for hotels but this one...well it deserves it.From the moment the cab pulled up outside, to second we departed five days later, I could not fault the service and attention given to us by the employees of this hotel. Seriously, the management should be so proud of the tight ship they run here. On our way back to the airport on the return journey, the bell boy got us a gorgeous, luxurious car to take us back, and it only cost $5 more than a cab.We got the room to our key in under 5 minutes and were in our room in under 10 (the only thing keeping us waiting was the queue for the lifts but we hit a slight busy period) The room was smallish but I didn't expect anything bigger, the bathroom lovely - great large easy to access shower - and increadibly comfortable bed.We also tried the restaurant on the last night and wish we had tried it sooner. We has a rib-eye steak burger and the cheesy chips...nothing has come close since.The hotel is closely located to The Empire State Building, Macy's etc (roughly a 10 minute walk) and also close to Madison Square Park, which was delightful to sit in and we got to watch some of the American Open on our final day. There are a great range of shops, restaurants and bars nearby and the location is perfect for those who do not wan't to be too deep in the hustle of Times Square and need something cheeper than the Upper West Side.I could write and praise this hotel until I am blue in the face. When I can come back, this will be the only choice for me. If I did have one criticism, it was that the windows didn't block out a lot of the noise and our room was on the front. However we had ear plugs and I am just now nitpicking.Seriously, thank you to everyone at this hotel for making my first trip to New York, so memorable.

Stayed here for 2 nights over a holiday weekend. It's located close enough to tourist attractions to be convenient but not in the mix. I've seen some comments about noise but i suspect that's a suburbanites reaction to a large city. Our room was in the center so we heard nothing from the street, the king bed room was a great size for a room in NYC (most of them are barely 200 sq ft, this one was a good size), well decorated and clean. There are many hotels in this neighborhood, but i was pleasantly surprised with the Hilton and would totally go back. I'd recommend it particularly for business travelers, couples, friends or a solo trip.
user_name:
deeflyy
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: A small new typical Hilton that could be improved eventually. We had a nice, clean room with a great view on the lower New York. Some minor problems were solved thanks to the good willing of the people in the hotel. The security level was satisfactory for the hotel(nobody uses lifts without the room card-key) and the area as well. The breakfast on the other hand has nothing to do with the Europen Hiltons breakfast, was really poor in choices(the buffet), they were running out to shop whatever was finished(bagels, bananas, yogurt) which looked to us a little paculiar. You could alternative order from a menu a limited(but delicious i must say) choice.The RARE restaurant and bar was wonderful, great dishes, friendly service, the best Mohito(made by Sara), clean and nice atmosphere!!! We would choose the same hotel hoping the next time small malfunctions will find their solution.

The location was good for me; close to where I was traveling for work. While the room was a bit small; I believe it is standard size for NYC. The decor was modern, which was perfect for me. The TV was nice; a coffee maker; good shower. The staff at the front desk was nice.

I liked 1) excellent location, with so much within a half mile 2) hotel is new or very recently refurbished 3) room showers are very goodI didn't like 1) poor noise insulation from windows 2) very claustrophobic feel (business centre was half the size of a household washroom!) 3) failing technology (TV kept shutting off; elevator swipe cards seldom worked)

Stayed here in December 2011 for just 1 night. The room was great. The design and layout worked well. The sheets were a little scratchy but it's a Hilton, not a Waldorf. The hotel is located close to subways and the breakfast was tasty. I would definitely come back on my next trip if the rate was good.

rooms are on the smaller size, although my room had two double size beds, all very clean and modern, very quiet, I was near the top floor, great bathroom products, staff very friendly and helpful, breakfast was average, not much choice and nothing seemed very healthy.I was happy you could open the windows a small way to let in some fresh air.I received all benifits and was recognised as a Diamond member of the Hilton Hotel programme.Good value if you stay outside peak periods (i.e New Year Eve).

We checked in the Hilton New York Fashion District hotel on Wednesday December 28th and checked out on January 2nd. I have visited New York prior to this trip and surprisingly, this was a very quiet neighborhood. Our biggest concern and information you should know is that it was almost impossible to check in early. Although we had requested an early check in, the hotel was fully booked and they were unable to accommodate us. The front desk however, was willing to place our luggage in their luggage room and we were given a call when our room was available. This hotel has a feature where you need your key to use the elevator, which made us feel a little safer being in the building. We also constantly had to request towels and toilet paper and each and every single time they responded within 10-15 minutes. Our turn down service and housekeeping was immaculate, you could definitely tell that house keeping had been there to clean/pick up. We ordered room service from RARE and all of our meals were delicious and it seemed that they were sent up as soon as they were ready. This is one of the only times I would suggest ordering a steak from room service. The surrounding area made it really easy to walk to the Flatiron Building, the Empire State Building, and surrounding metro stops. There's a bar across the street, but Rougue nearby was much more fun. I would definitely recommend this hotel for a family, or business trip since it was nice and quiet. However, if you're looking for a hipper area, try the Upper West Side or Greenwhich Village.

My wife and I had to postpone our planned tropical getaway 10th anniversary trip, and thought we were "settling" when we went to NY for an overnight. While it wasn't the tropics, the staff at this Hilton couldn't have done a better job making our weekend special! All I did was put a a little footnote in my reservation on Hilton.com that we were celebrating our anniversary and who knew I'd end up with complimentary champagne and chocolates and a hand written note in our room congratulating us upon arrival in our room. We arrived at the hotel in the morning and an extremely friendly young women behind the desk addressed me by name, congratulated me on our anniversary once she pulled up my reservation, and answered all my questions about dining and parking. She had a room ready for us but asked me if I'd be willing to wait, check my bags w/ bell hop until a room on a higher floor w/ view of Empire State Bldg was cleaned and ready. I agreed to wait for the room w/ the view, which she provided at no added cost, though the website offers them for a higher rate than other rooms. We set out sight seeing for the day and returned to get our keys. The same women came out from behind the desk, greeted me by name just as I entered the door, congratulated my wife on our occasion, handed us our keys, and offered us cupcakes. She was super sweet and deserves an A+ for her hospitality. She got a bellman over to promptly deliver our bags. Hallway are narrow, but not atypical of any other NY hotel. Room was relatively small, but brand new, and modern. Minibar was stocked, though we didn't use it. We were provided with instructions on how to access rooftop bar and given info on dining. We saw a Broadway show that night and took in the sights, so never made it to the rooftop, but in the short time we spent in this hotel, the service was top notch, the bed was super comfortable, and I couldn't have asked for anything more. And for the rate I got, it was a better experience in other NYC hotels where I've paid double or sometimes triple. The location is perfect, just south of MSG, in the Fashion District, short walk to the subway, and plenty of quick food options nearby. I find it a good spot to get some peace and quiet but easily access anything needed in NY. I walked to Herald Square in about 5 mins, made it to both Times Square and the Financial district in about 10 mins on the subway. I highly recommend you give this place a shot!

I have just stayed for a week at the Hilton Hotel Fasion District NYC. I chose this hotel as I am a diamond status member of the Hilton group. Breakfast and internet access were therefore complementary. The latter proved particularly useful. In addition, in chosing a NYC hotel, I decided that there would be no more certain a way to spoil a holiday than to experience problems with bed bugs. Accordingly, I chose this hotel as there have been no reports of any infestations. I experienced no problems with bugs, and needles to say, this was a source of great relief. The rooms are small, modern and clean. The staff were quite friendly and down to earth, and overall the hotel represents good value for a budget stay.My biggest disappointment was with the buffet breakfast which had very limited and poor quality food choices. All of these choices were very unhealthy expect for the fresh apples, oranges and bananas. I would not recommend getting breakfast included in your stay at this hotel, particularly if you are health conscious. You would do better to go to a diner or local deli/supermarket and find fresh food that is not full of sugar and fats.

The hotel was great. Very nice and clean interior. Rooms and lobby were well decorated. The room was decent sized and the price was high but good for NYC for the quality received. The staff was great. Bell service was quick. They even let us drop off our bags before we checked in and leave them after we checked out so we didn't have to haul them around with us. A quick walk down 7th Ave. from Penn Station and just two subway stops from Times Square. In fact Rockefeller Center, The Empire State Building, Broadway shows, and lots of other stuff is all within a mile from the hotel. We could see the Empire State Building from the hotel window since we were on one of the higher up levels. It isn't even too far from Central Park. We would definitely stay again.
user_name:
Neal M
Ames, Iowa, United States

review_body: We stayed there December 22 and checked out December 23. We have stayed there before and enjoyed the hotel. It is newly renovated and has a nice, streamlined, modern look. This time, we had a bad experience. We booked two rooms (room 308 and 311). On the checkout date, our friend in room 311 took her bag and left it in our room. When we returned at 11:30 to the room (checkout is noon), we discovered 1) key card to our room had been nullified; 2) key card to her room still worked, but when we opened the door, the room had been fully made up with other people's belongings in her room. We went downstairs to complain because apparently the room was being used by someone else even though we haven't checked out. Front desk was unbelievably rude. Cut us off. Wouldn't even let us explain our full story. They repeated over and over that it is policy to put others' luggage in the room on the checkout date if there is no luggage of guest (in whose name room was under) in room, as guest often leaves without officially checking out. Granted, that might be their policy, but we still have the room until 12 noon and others' belongings shouldn't be in the room. In fact, we could have damaged another guest's belongings as we had full access their luggage. Despite the bad policy, we would have been not so upset had they been more considerate. Instead, they were rude. Manager came up. Was not rude but was very surly. Not once was there an apology "we're sorry to inconvenience you. we're sorry it happened. We understand your feeling." Nothing. Later, when we returned to pick up our luggage from the hotel from the luggage room, one of the hotel clerks gossiped about us to his colleague, pointing to us "they were mad, etc." as if we weren't there. o make

We stayed here from Dec 24 to 27 and thought it was fantastic. The room was fantastic, cozy but typical for a hotel in NYC. Very clean, modern, great bathroom and shower. A moderate walk or cab ride to any destination. Bar was great but limited hours. Fitness center was adequate for a quick work out. Bellman was great - stood out in the pouring rain to hail us a cab, even after 3 cabs turned him down bc their shift was ending. I will definitely stay here again.
This hotel was very clean and the staff was very friendly and professional. Breakfast at Rare was very good.

We spent 6 nights at this Hotel over Christmas. The hotel entrance is set back from the street on 26th Street just off 7th Avenue (between 6th & 7th) and has a funky foyer with friendly reception staff and concierge between 8am-8pm. I requested a high room facing the Empire State Building based on advice here and were given a room on level 17 but on the other side of the hotel with no views. Our room was very very small, on the emergency exit map you can see that on the Empire State side there are 7 rooms and on the opposite side there are also 7 rooms but these include the 3 elevators and emergency exits to stairwells so space is a premium on the elevator side. Our room was very modern and clean with a very comfortable king sized bed, there was a small desk and chair and a small wardrobe with a safe. We had 2 large bags and had nowhere to put them apart from on the floor as there wasn't enough room to store clothes in the wardrobe. As such they were on the floor and we had to squeeze around them. I guess that you don't spend much time in the room apart from sleeping but it was a pain when we were in our room. I suggest you travel lightly (bit difficult though when you are from Australia).The room was very quiet on the 17th level apart from the noisy air conditioning unit in the room which we had to leave on most of the time for our comfort. We both slept with ear plugs because of this. Beware of the mini bar system, if you remove an item you can't put it back and are charged electronically. We didn't use the mini-bar but on our 3rd day a staff member arrived to restock the mini bar and replenished several items which of course were used by a previous guest. Of course at check out all of the replenished items were on our bill, thankfully the staff removed these without any fuss.There is a bar in the lobby and also a wonderful roof top bar which is great to see the city lights at night including the Empire State Building. You can enjoy a very nice meal in Rare Bar & Grill. We had 2 meals here and loved the lollipop chicken wings (very spicy) and the cobb salad and grilled salmon salad.There is also an ATM and 2 complimentary computers in the lobby but no free wi-fi. The closest subways are the 1 train on 28th Street & 7th Avenue or the N-R-W train on 28th Street & Broadway. You are very close to Madison Square Garden and Macy's. Get up to Korea Town on 32nd Street and Broadway for some great Korean food, or great burgers at Shake Shack in Madison Square Park (opposite Flatiron building) and don't miss Eataly (also opposite Madison Square Park on Broadway.The Hotel was very clean and nice with friendly staff although a little bit secluded from all the action but reasonably close to the Subway. It was also reasonably priced for New York.

There is really not much to say about this Hilton. Its pretty unremarkable by every measure, and that isn't necessarily a bad thing for a New York hotel. Pros:-No executive lounge, so breakfast is downstairs at Rare. I've actually decided this is a good thing since the food is good and has a lot of options. Hilton Times Square has the same deal since they don't have an executive lounge either.-Rooms are nice, and the size is fine. People that are saying the rooms are small obviously haven't stayed in a lot of hotels in new york. If you want to see tiny go to a courtyard, hampton inn, element, or any of the really tall narrow hotels. The rooms are probably between 200-300 sq ft which is definitely smaller than the Hilton Times Square, but comparable to Hilton New York, the W and a lot of other hotels in the City.-The location is pretty good. Its a couple blocks from the subway, walking distance to a lot of good food in Chelsea, close to Penn Station. Its definitely a hike to Times Square, Central Park etc but doable if you like to walk.-It was way cheaper than other hotels. I was originally planning to stay elsewhere but it dropped to 109 a night in the winter whereas others were barely under 250. Cons:-Like others mentioned about the elevators, its a lot of floors for a few elevators, it wasn't packed until my last day there and the rooftop bar closed early and there was still a lot of waiting around for a packed elevator.-No executive lounge for those that careSome of the other reviews mentioned issues with the rooms or staff, I had no problems with either. Its hard to pick a favorite New York hotel since I've had good experiences with quite a few over the years. I'll certainly add this hotel to my list of good experiences and will probably be back.
user_name:
lovewell
New York City, New York

review_body: I had a great stay at this Hilton. The place was CLEAN and fun. I wanted to stay some place near Penn Station and this was just a few blocks away. The restaurants provided good food and service. The roof deck was a nice fun surprise, what a great view.
A good spot slightly off the beaten path. New interiors done well. Very close to a Whole Foods Market, which is very handy.

We went to NYC specifically to see a broadway show (On a clear day you can see forever-Harry Connick Jr.-AMAZING).I foolishly booked the tickets in July not realizing it was Thanksgiving (we're Canadian!) and also, black Friday (who knew?!?). We were pretty worried about cost and flights were already completely outrageous so we were suggested this hotel by a friend who lives in NYC but had never stayed there.It was perfect-again, we don't care much about room size as we are barely in them but it was clean, had coffee for the morning and the staff were extremely accomodating for all things-luggage storage-directions-ideas-VERY friendly.We ate at the restaurant as well which was a nice steak house with great service, and friendly staff as well. There's also a rooftop cocktail bar which was a nice option when we were tired. The cost was reasonable through hotels.com and I imagine it would be more so--on another weekend. We would stay there again for sure-it's located close to many things (we walked to Times Square and Central Park-which were pretty far but it is also close to 5th ave and other major landmarks). We took the subway as well which was cheap and quick. Try it, it's a nice little spot.

This Hilton is relatively new. Rooms are small, even by NYC standards. Staff are not very guest-oriented even to Hilton top-tier HHonor guests. When I mentioned two housekeeping issues at check out I didn't even get an apology. When I wanted to extend my stay by arriving early, even though rooms were available, they wouldn't extend my pricing. Business center is a joke -- two old pcs running Windows XP! It is an acceptable property but there are certainly nicer Hilton and Hilton-family properties in NYC.

This is a very pleasant NYC four-star. As a Diamond, I was upgraded to a 22nd floor room looking out across to the Empire State Building. A small but comfortable room with some effort taken to make it contemporary and chic to fit the 'fashion district' name. Bathroom has a shower but no tub (no big issue on my part).Staff at the front desk were excellent and very helpful - and remembered my name. The lobby isn't large, but there were handmade cupcakes on offer whenever I passed through. The rooftop bar has some excellent views, but isn't anything to write home about - it's New York, there are much better venues. I had the a la carte breakfast in the basement restaurant - again, friendly service and a decent selection (I'd recommend this over the buffet).I used the wrong credit card on checking out, and again, front desk and accounts staff were very efficient in fixing this.The hotel is convenient for Chelsea and Midtown, and there are subway stations within a two-block walk. An easy walk from Penn Station. If you don't need a pool or much no-fuss - I'd recommend this property - I'd stay again.

Location and rooms are great. Quality of service is mediocre (e.i. Concierge couldn't get out of her podium to get the doorman for me when it was raining heavily and I didn't have an ombrella). They have a roof bar or some type of lounge up there which means tons of drunks are hanging around the lobby as of happy hour! Once, coming into the elevator I shared it with had 3 tipsy guys which we're not guests of the hotel and kept trying to get to the top floor. I didn't feel safe at all!! Should I add that one night costed $450 us! The restaurant in the hotel is pretty good.

Found staff to be friendly and helpful. We got a room upgrade on 22nd floor with a lovely view of Empire State building. Location convenient to Flat Iron, Chelsea Market, Meat Packing.It would be nice if you did not have to have ice delivered (no ice machines), but they delivered quickly so can't really complain.Have stayed in about 8 different places in Manhattan and would definitely stay here again.

I stay in NYC frequently with work, sometimes for pleasure. I stayed here this past Thursday for under $300.00 and frankly, this is one of the best accomodations I have stayed at in NY in a long time. Stayed at the W in Union Square a few months back for $400 and the rooms here were much nicer. Location is great, staff was great, really enjoyed it. I was only taken back by one thing. RARE is the name of thier bar/restaurant on the first floor and the rooftop bar. The rooftop bar has one of the most spectacular views in NYC if the Empire State Bldg. For some odd reason, the management is trying to make this into some sort of exclusive club. You have to go through a security check (which is bascially a guy at the elevator) and then you are escorted in the elevator to the roof. All for effect. In the club, there are numerous oversized bouncers in tuxedos watching over everyone. What is laughable is when you look at the crowd there. Anyone can get in, no dress code, basically your typical corner bar crowd. I would love to sit there and enjoy a drink but the pathetic show they are trying to put on overshadows what should be a cool, relaxed place to have some fun. The place is not the Gansevoort, so don't try to imitate it.

Hotel is on 26th Street off 7th Ave within walking distance to subways, Penn Station, 34st shops and Madison Square Garden. It is not convenient to Broadway shows. Rates tend to be lower than other Hilton Hotels in the city. The lobby is dark and small with little seating. Check-in was efficient and polite and I was on my way to the room in only a few minutes. The room is small but not unusual for NY standards in similar priced hotels. Bathoom is small but adequate. The shower was great with good water pressure. Although there was a luggage rack provided, it was totally useless - too small to hold even my small carry-on. I needed to place my luggage on the floor! There is a coffee maker but there is no ice machine available at all. Ice needed to be ordered through room service with a charge of $3.00!

I travel regularly for work and have stayed so many nights with this particular hotel that I've gotten used to it. The upside is I always know where I am going and have set up a bit of comfort zone around the many nights I've stayed here. The downside is the customer service of the front desk as well as the room service staff.Bell Staff is fantastic -- consistently sweet, forward thinking, positive, happy to grab a cab for me. One bell staff employee even refused my $5.00 tip the last night I was there as he was happy to call the cab for us after having stayed in the hotel for the previous 5 nights and tipping him well each time they assisted us.Cons: Whoever is answering the room service line in the morning sounds like they are 15 years old, have no idea what they are doing, always forgets something (like cups when i ordered only a pot of coffee, or creamer) or utensils when I order food. Pretty ridiculous when I'm already paying a premium on food (which i'm fine with), delivery service, 18% surcharge and approximately $75 per night in "hotel fee's" on top of the $225 - $399 rate I pay nightly for each stay. Also, after every order (morning, noon or night), room service always calls 10 minutes after delivery to ask me to put my tray outside my door, which just ticks me off. It interrupts me, as well as on these last two nights I was here, both times the trays were left outside the door at 8pm and not picked up until almost 2pm the next day. they had even put my morning newspaper right next to it so its not like they didn't pass directly in front of my door.Hilton Fashion District, you're about to lose this Diamond Status Member, as well as my coworkers that I've booked stays here for too, someone who loyally stays with you nearly every other week and currently has three weeks of reservations in January. Comp'ing my breakfast is no longer going to cut it and make up for these avoidable, sloppy errors. I'm too busy at work to deal with little stuff like this. I want to come back to my room, have it be cleaned without having to ask, have my trays picked up and carry on.
user_name:
fritoboater
New York City, New York

review_body: A friend and I decided to go to New York for a long weekend to do some much needed shopping. It was fairly last minute so we didn't have a lot of time to research hotel options. We chose this hotel as it was in the area we wanted to be in and had a good rate through Expedia.ca. The location turned out to be very good as you could walk to many stores or hop on the subway which was not too far away. It is close to things but not in the thick of it which is my preference.The hotel is new and clean but as it is a big chain hotel there is not much in the way of charm but was nicely decorated. My only complaint about the lobby is that it annoyed me that in the evening one elevator was taken off service for the rooftop bar so you had to wait awhile and it was usually quite full. The rooms were quite large considering this is New York. The bathroom had lots of counter space and was clean which is all that I ask for. My only complaint about the room is that the doors bang shut very loudly and I was startled awake a few times in the night when a neighbour would return to their room. It may be because our room was at the end of the hall and the noise echoed in the small alcove we were in. Having said that though the beds were very comfortable and I did manage to get a good night sleep most nights.There aren't too many options for breakfast close by the hotel but the porter told us about the Malibu Diner on 23rd just east of 7th which was fast and and good value. We ate there for lunch our first day and then went back for breakfast another day and it was good food both times. There is a tea shop called Argo on the corner that had excellent tea (the best I've had outside of England, which I know isn't saying much but it was very good) and they also had good muffins.All of the staff were very polite and helpful and the doormen and porters in particular were very helpful recommending places to eat getting us cabs.Helpful hint: if you are arriving on veterns day keep in mind the parade starts near this hotel and traffic is worse than usual for the cab ride from the La Guardia if you happen to land mid morning.

The Staff here were outstanding! My best man booked for my bachelor party on the wrong weekend and we faced some terrible hassle from bookings.com/expedia.com . So I called the hotel and the management/supervisory team was outstanding and rebooked us without a hassle. The hotel itself looks great in the lobby, restaurant, rooftop bar and the rooms.Had a great time! Thanks again Lynda Spair for everything !

We were pleasantly surprised by this hotel in NYC. We were very close to Madison Square Garden and several great restaurants. The hotel was very cool and modern. The rooms were small but very clean and decorated in a very chic, hip way.Our room had a Keureg coffee maker and several great snacks available. The TV in the room was definitely on the newer side and was completely interactive. The staff at the front desk were extremely professional and pleasant. The first thing we noticed (and liked for our safety) was that the elevators have staff in front of each one and the only way to operate the elevator is to use your key card then press your floor. Very safe and secure.We slept very well. The room was extremely quiet, very nice bed and linens as well.We will definitely stay here again.

My mom and I stayed at the Hilton NY Fashion District in October. After having to go back and forth to Kleinfeld for wedding dress fittings, we decided to stay over one night instead of sitting on the train for 3 hours in one day. The hotel was clean, nicely decorated and the staff were helpful. We enjoyed the free samples of Baked by Melissa cupcakes in the lobby :) We paid with AMEX points, so I can't comment on the cost, but I enjoyed our one-night stay and would recommend this hotel.

We booked a few days here in early October to attend a friend's wedding in NY. This was my 3rd or 4th stay in NYC and I thought the location and price of the stay was by far the best compared to earlier experiences. The hotel is NEWER which meant a lot to me & was clean and modern. We booked the queen room and have no complaints. Not a great view, staff was standoffish. Interesting security, we had to swipe our hotel room key to get on/off the elevators. Al in all, I was so pleased with my experience, we booked here for another wedding March 2012. The room rate for the queen was around $180!! How can that be beat for a new hotel room in NYC?

I've stayed at virtually every Hilton in New York City. Many are okay; none are exceptional frankly. However, this Hilton is a nice property. The hotel is pretty new (2010). LIke many hotels in NYC the rooms are small. But they do well with the limited space. The beds are nice, good work area, nice bathroom with upgraded bath ammenties and a nice flat screen. The design and decor of the hotel fits its location- the Fashion District. The service however, ranks much higher than other Hiltons. There is a strong sense of service here and it's evident. The only downside to the hotel- to me- is the onsight restaurant, Rare. It's an upscale burger bar, but that's really all they have. The breakfast isn't good and the dinner consists of virtually all burgers- which if you don't want a burger, isn't going to give you what you want. But, there are a ton of restaurants very close by. Overall- this is a B+/A- property.

To start, I very much enjoyed staying in this hotel; I travel to NY frequently and have stayed at many properties from Chelsea to midtown, and this was one of my favorites. Our room was quiet, spotless, and the service was excellent. The beds were VERY comfortable, and the bathroom/shower were wonderful, very spa like. Also, there is a Keurig in the room for coffee, and a 37" wall mounted HD tv. Lastly, the rooftop bar was a beautiful space, enclosed with lots of seating and amagnificent view. Everyone we encountered was friendly and helpful; I would absolutely stay here again.However, there are 3 minor issues that some travelers may find fault with: (1) no fridge in the room; (2) no ice machienes (you call room service to have it delivered); and (3) very limited selection of tv channels. These are very minor inconvienences when compared to the positive aspects of the hotel; however, they may matter to some.Other items worth mentioning about the area; Chelsea is wonderful and only a 5 minute subway ride on the 1 train to all major attractions (subway one block away on 27th St). Also, if you stay, do not miss the following eateries:1. Brooklyn Bagels on 8th Avenue between 26th and 25th (best NY bagels you'll find)2. Two Bros Pizza on 6th Ave and 25th st (Excellent pizza for $1 per slice, open 24 hours)3. The Doughnut Plant on 23rd between 7th and 8th, next to Hotel Chelsea. Quite possibly the best doughnut ever. Try the yeast donuts. Amazing.All in all, I would gladly return to this hotel: clean, quiet and comfortable, all in a great neighboorhood.

After seeing the prices for 4-star hotels in Midtown, we found the Hilton in the Fashion District (W. 26th at 7th Ave. near and across from the FIT) this past weekend. The hotel is very new and clean, nice shower/bathroom area, less expensive than midtown hotels ($349/night + taxes, $55/day valet parking), friendly and competent staff. It is convenient to the #1 train to go up Broadway. The only downside is that the wait for the elevators is longer than it should be. It seems that the algorithm being used to route the elevators needs reworking so they don't always go to the lobby when not in use. We ate a light dinner one night in the bar on the first floor (RARE) which was quite good (I had chili and Lisa had soup). We'll definitely stay here again; we much preferred it to the Sheraton and New York Hilton in midtown which are also 4-star properties. It's smaller, less busy, newer and cleaner than those properties.
Very good location. Rooms were kind of small but very neat and comfortable. Nice bar in hotel. Would definitely stay there again!

(SERVICE) I recently stayed at the Hilton Fashion District this past week/weekend on my first trip to New York City. Prior to arriving to the hotel I encountered some hiccups with booking the hotel. I notified Elle Lee of my issues and I must say that she went above and beyond in every aspect. She not only ensured that the issue was resolved prior to the stay, but she followed up during, and even after the stay! This customer service did not stop with Elle, every time I passed an employee whether it was a member of the maid service or a maintenance individual, each one made sure to greet me, ask me how my stay was, and wish me a well day. My friend and I were also late getting back to the hotel (we overlooked the correct checkout time) and the staff was very understanding. (HOTEL) The hotel is exactly as pictured on the internet. It is clean, modern, and situated well for individuals wanting to visit far south areas like the World Trade Center Memorial and Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island or Northern sites like Central Park and Times Square because it is a short walk to the 23rd/28th/34th subway stations. I personally walked to Rockefeller and it was an easy walk. The rooms are a bit on the smaller side from what I'm used to (but from reading other reviews, it is larger than the average New York hotel) , but It is a small trade off compared to some of the other hotels where I saw that guests have to share a community bathroom! I also did not experience any of the noise from the street or from the rooftop during my stay (19th floor), and when I walked the street early in the morning or later at night I did not hear any of the noise. In fact, I believe there was a sign on the street for drivers that notified them that there would be a fine of $350 if they honked their horn, and it was video enforced.  (CONCLUSION) Great Hotel, Great Location, Great Service, Great Price, Great Place to Stay for Your NYC Trip!

Just returned to the UK after 4 days in NYC, stayed at this hotel firstly because I have never had a bad experience at a Hilton hotel and secondly because of the reviews. This is a modern clean and comfortable hotel to which I would happily return, the rooms are fine and bathroom spotless. Contrary to some of the reviews, I found the staff to be polite and knowledgeable and have absolutely no complaints. We ate at Rare the steak house attached to the restaurant we thought it was excellent a meal for four people including wine and 2 rounds of drinks prior to dinner cost $260 inc tip, as for the drink prices well $12 for a GnT which was so strong I had to ask for more tonic didnt strike me as poor value as far as hotel prices go. This hotel is in a brilliant location, a short walk up 7th to Macy's and then a shorter walk into Times Sq, used to tube to get around no problems at all. Couple of places we thought were outstanding, Merchants River House Battery Park the best burger I have ever had 4 meals all different all excellent 2 rounds of drinks $98 fantastic great views across the Hudson of the statue of lib. Secondly the Museum not my usual cup of tea, However I had a great day. Two irish bars worthy of a mention Lanigans passed the red steps on the right side street ( excellent food) amd O'Donahueys very similar.Well done Hilton

I've stayed in a few hotels in midtown manhattan and I've learnt never to set my expectations too high. If you do, you're often disappointed. So that was my approach with the Hilton Fashion Dist. What I got though was a really outstanding hotel with great service, great rooms and an overall outstanding experience. The rooms are a decent size, and the way they are furnished makes them better to use than many larger ones. Clean, modern, homely and quiet yet still really funky. Everything has been thought out well to make the best use of space. The housekeeping staff were fantastic and having little extras get such as the safe, iron and iPod docks really do make a massive difference (especially if you don't pack your iPhone charger!)The bars were great and reasonable, and Rare View really does make you feel like you're in a movie with its fantastic views across downtown and midtown. The staff were all incredibly polite and friendly, and always looked to help in any way they could. They weren't pretentious or snobby as you can sometimes find. A really great assert to this hotel. I would stay here again, although I have two minor suggestions and one major criticism. The criticism - $15 a day for wifi is ridiculous. Seriously, this adds on to the price of the room, and I'll be honest, I will be calculating it in when I next look at hotels in midtown. It's a rip off and I've never paid that much for wifi anywhere. Suggestions - the mirrors could be better placed - having only one on the bathroom door away from a good source of light is a nightmare when getting ready. Also MORE CUPCAKES! They're lovely, but in four days I only saw them once!Sort the wifi out and I won't give other hotels a thought.

Stayed here for 1 night on stopover while traveling from Melbourne to Orlando. Hotel looks new and well cared for.Staff on check in were warm and friendly and knew that I hade been traveling over 24 hours.Nice room on 22 floor. No noise as suggested by other reviewers.Room was a little small, and lighting was so gloomy in entrance that I needed a torch to use the in room safe.Great digital HD TV, reasonably priced auto-mini bar. Nice coffee available.No complaints. Great stay in a good hotel.

We stayed there 3 nights while visiting NYC this past weekend and absolutely loved it! The rooms were very clean (a little small), but were functional! The staff were super nice. We came back from being out all day to an unclean room and the bathroom light not working - we called and maintenance was there with in 2 minutes and housekeeping with in 5 minutes. We loved going to the restaurant that was next to us to have drinks and also really enjoyed the roof top bar! The location was great too!! I would highly recommend this room to anyone going to NYC! We will be staying there for sure the next visit we have.

I had some issues with my reservation and rate before I got to the hotel, but the hotel manager worked to make things right. The location of the hotel is phenomenal and provided quick access to the convention center, Penn Station and Times Square. The lobby of the hotel is small, but serves its purpose. The front desk staff was friendly and attentive and the check in and check out process was smooth and fast... They even held my bag for me after I checked out.I had a higher floor king bed room and the view was amazing. The bed was comfy, TV was big and there was even a Keurig machine with free k cups! In the bathroom the water was hot and had great pressure.The return in the lobby had great drinks and friendly staff and there was even a roof bar!I will definitely stay here again
user_name:
Jay R
Baltimore, Maryland, United States
