review_body: The hotel is ok; the rooms are a little small, but other than that a pretty standard chain hotel set-up. But it's in a great location in Chelsea.On the first morning, the hotel's Internet connection was down for two hours; just when we were trying to plan what to do for the day! On the next morning, the TV signal went down.

We spent one night, November 27, 2011, at this great boutique hotel. When we arrived early in the afternoon, we remarked to the staff that it looked strikingly reminiscent of a hotel by the name of Fashion 26 where we stayed several times months ago. And the staff told us smilingly that it's the same hotel, and Fashion 26 was the previous incarnation prior to Hilton took over in Feb 2011.It was obviously a stressful day, but the staff, especially Christine, who pleasantly went way beyond the calls of duty to find us a beautiful room with luminous view of the Empire State building. The room was not ready when we checked in, but as soon as it was, Christine called us informing us so we could settle ourselves at our earliest conveniences. Another staff, Zoribel, went out of her way to make sure our luggage would arrive at our room in a timely fashion.Stunning view from the roof-top bar, but unfortunately it was closing a little early since it was Thanksgiving Sunday.Very comfortable bed, spacious bedroom and bathroom (great shower but no bathtub) and, in between, there is this lighted area that contained the mini-fridge and the coffee machine (it looks like a small open curio cabinet) was set up in a very aesthetically pleasing way.One slight disappointment: there is no ice machine on any floor, and we had to call room service for ice. I sustained a black eye earlier in the afternoon from an incident at a friend's place, so the difficulty of obtaining ice that evening was a little inconvenient.In the morning, another very competent and friendly staff, Caroline, checked us out. Also, the bell captain (I believe his name was Allen) was very helpful, as was everyone else.

I really like the fact that the Hilton Fashion District New York has taken the time to respond to any negative trip advisor reviews however they don't seem to have taken any of the reviewers' comments on board judging by my recent stay over thanks giving weekend. We notified the hotel that we would be checking in around midnight, they responded promptly but alas when we did arrive it took the concierge sometime to locate someone to check us in. First impressions of the hotel aside from this were good, it was a great location just on 7th Ave making it equally accessible to travelling uptown and downtown with a stylish lobby and the concierge was very friendly and welcoming. The room was small but very clean, we had requested a room with a view and we were situated on the 20th floor with a view of the Empire State. However the room was very stuffy and the aircon was incredibly loud and inefficient. The bathroom had a great powerful shower and generally for the amount of time we were planning to spend in the room it was sufficient for our needs. When we checked out at 6 am in the morning we were surprised to find the lobby devoid of any staff so we were unable to check out and we left our room keys on the desk. Generally I can understand why there are negative comments, for the cost of the stay you may find better hotels but you would probably find much worse. In summary a better presence of staff would improve the welcome overall, there is nightclub noise if you are on a high floor, the staff seemed a bit surly when approached, the room is small and the aircon is noisy but it's a good location, it's clean and it's functional.

We stayed in Hilton for 4 days while we were in New York and we enjoyed our stay there everynight. Staff was very helpful and friendly and they managed to get as a room as soon as we arrived even before noon. Room was good sized and it fit 3 huge bags in it and we were still comfortable in the room. Beds very comfortable and room very clean. The complimentary coffe in the room is a plus. Location is very convenient you can find plenty of coffe shops and reasturants close by. The penn station is 5-8 minutes walk from the hotel.

You can't beat it for the price, I got a room off Kayak for $139 for 2 nights. It's not a new property but has had a lot of money put into it. All the signs of Hilton quality are there, great staff, comfy beds, linens, flat screen blah blah blah blah. The problem is the noise level. Housekeeping bangs the doors around like you wouldn't believe. I mean everytime the housekeeper next door went to the cart, the door banged closed. On top of that they really cheaped out on the framing of the hallway doors. Meaning, at night you can see light all the way around the door coming from the hall. Which means you here everything. Plus, they must have gotten a deal on the toilets. You can hear them flushing from other rooms. Great price but would rather pay more for a good night sleep!

New property, with good value in NYC. Professional staff and up to date rooms make a stay at this central location a great stay. The roof top bar has some great views of the city. The only negative thing I can say it the toilets are very noisy and the automatic light in the bathroom can be a pain.

For the price to value ratio, this is one of the best deals in New York. The rooms are spotless and the beds great and while the rooms are not nearly as large as those at the flagship Hilton on 6th Avenue you have to consider how much time you spend in a hotel room in New York anyway? The staff is very friendly and helpful and the location means you're going to have to take a cab pretty much everywhere - but overall a teriffic value. We will stay there again.

The Hilton in the Fashion District of Manhattan is a nice new hotel - very trendy lobby and rooms to match. We had a king room and it was spacious with a comfy bed, desk area, flat screen TV and beautiful bathroom. The rooms are presented beautifully and are impeccably clean.The service is outstanding. The majority of the desk staff are very easy to deal with and go out of their way to help you. Only downside of service was when we moved rooms (our choice), our bags were moved so roughly that a few items broke...which we weren't too happy with.Location is good - 2 blocks from a Metro station which is the only way to travel in NYC. Plenty of places to eat around and Macy's flagship store a short walk away. Times Square only 2 stations away.Good value hotel in the area. The rooms could be better insulated for sound as you hear a fair amount of noise no matter where your room is (from outside and from neighbouring rooms) but still got sleep.Would have been nice to have a couple of extra facilities like a guest laundry (though there is a laundromat across the street for holiday-ers who like to keep on top of their washing!). Gym is small but serviceable for what you'd need.All in all, very pleased with pretty much everything with this hotel! Would definitely stay here again when in NYC.

the room was very comfortable,the bathroom too.Very clean hotel and near the center.it's a very good choise if you want to visit NYC for a few days.i think that the price was good ,because in NY usualy the hotels are very expencive.

stayed here in august 2010 it was great and was owned by Wyndham. May 2011 we stayed again and found out that Hilton owned it now and the service and the look of the hotel wasn't as nice anymore. there is a roof top bar that we loved so we were excited to go again. On this one particular night we wanted to go to the bar the guy in charge of the elevator (only way to get to the bar) asked if we were guests of the hotel? yes, we are you have only seen us here every day for the past couple of days and on occasion even said hello to us.So then he told us we had to wait for the next elevator, so we sat and waited. These girls came in from the street and the elevator doorman (whatever his title is) was all excited to see them and was hugging them and when the elevator came down guess who got in before us? I would think guests of the hotel had priority? needless to say we finally got up there stayed for one hour and left. Other than that my trip to NY was amazing as always! Yankee game, shopping in soho and century 21,seeing the 911 site, central park. broadway shows, etc... planning next trip for NY 2012 and will be booking at the new holiday inn express across the street! Chelsea is in the hub so if u want to be near every thing this is the area to stay in.

Overall impersonal hotel. We stayed at a king size room and it was sufficiently spacious, however noise from the street could be heard at all times (remember that NY is the city that never sleeps). Breakfast buffet is scarce for European tastes.Staff was attentive, but we had serious problems with housekeeping as they forgot to clean the room several times (we had to call them to have it cleaned).Location is convenient and close to public transport.
A nice overall stay. Only one night, so perhaps not long enough to really get a good idea of the hotels amenities. I would stay here again when in NYC

Situated in Chelsea, it was the perfect location for a New York neophyte. Head north for a fair walk to MSG, Times Square, and Rockafeller Centre, and Central Park, but also close to the 1,2, and 3 lines. Go west and take a stroll on the Highline, and before you know it, you're in Greenwhich Village (you might as well head to SoHo). It's a busy area, and may be noisy for some, but I had not problem sleeping in the city that never sleeps. I hope to return to NYC, and I would gladly stay here again.

It's not often that you find a hotel in NYC where you have room to move! Beautiful hotel in the heart of NYC's fashion district... and it definitely fits the bill! Stayed here for a girls' weekend and we had a blast. The location was near Madison Sq Garden, etc... but it was a bit of a taxi ride everywhere else. Everyone working at the Hilton was extremely friendly and went out of their way to make us comfortable and aid in our sight seeing. In the end, we loved having a nice hotel to come back to at the end of a very busy day.

Stayed at this hotel in October 2011 and was very impressed by the hotel rooms and staff. The rooms were very comfortable and had a modern/contemporary feel to them.. a bit on the small side but in no way claustrophobic.The sfaff was extremely helpful - let us check in early, gave us a choice of rooms, hotel concierge was always available to help book tickets to various attractions and bell boys to hail a cab (even from across the block when there were none available readily).Minus one star for the location - fashion district, although close to many good eateries and shopping centers, Penn Station etc - we still needed a cab to go to the well known NY tourist attractions.

Just stayed two nights as a change from our typical stays near Times Square. The neighborhood is fine, and the staff were generally friendly. Rooms are nicely decorated and contemporary - and an excellent shower. A solid hotel, but neither distinctive nor remarkable. Be aware that even numbered rooms facing north to the street do get a lot of noise in the middle of the night (a problem if you sleep with the window open - or instead suffer the loud A/C unit) Rooftop bar was fun - until the music got too loud.

The rooms here are incredibly small and poorly-appointed. Also, we were on the 4th floor, facing 26th street, which was very loud. We live in New York, so expect a little noise, but the windows were single-pane and did not seal, and the doors hardly muffled the hallway and elevator noise. Thus, don't plan on a good night's sleep.The price can be matched by many other hotels in town, where you'll get so much more, in terms of space, luxury and relaxation. When we arrived (and throughout our stay), we were shocked to see this is listed by priceline (with whom we booked) as a 4 star hotel, as a big-name 3-star in New York (Four Points, Marriott, etc.) will give you much more. Clearly the emphasis is on the new coat of paint, LED lights and poorly-chosen dance music targeting weekend clubgoers, and with little thought put into the actual accommodation. Also, the team at this hotel does not have their act together. I witnessed arguing between the room staff and front desk staff, and constant mixed messages from each. Look elsewhere, you'll be happy you did

I had meetings in the vicinity and was coming into the city at Penn Station so this seemed like a convenient choice. Also, the rates (booked on the Hilton website) were very reasonable by New York standards. The location is great-- liked being near Chelsea and Union Square area. Lots of good restaurants, shopping and convenient subway stations. The hotel has that vaguely hip vibe--small lobby and hallways. The room was also small but fine for one person. I had a queen room on the 17th floor. Bed was comfortable, amenities were good. I'd stay again if I needed to be in that part of NY-- not grear, but fine.

Stayed here for one weekend night in November. The room was small but very comfortable and quiet. To me the most important aspect is the shower, especially after walking all day in the cold city. The Hilton definitely delivers with a spacious shower and plenty of hot water. The problem area was breakfast: the menu choices were great but they ran out of basic things like yogurts and milk (!) so it remained a good breakfast in theory... The staff explained that some deliveries were missed that day so I guess that's not the usual breakfast service you would get.

We took a chance on this hotel. Overall, it worked but the place was so poorly designed and the staff so rude, that I recommend you consider elsewhere. Positives-Roof top bar - The roof top bar is FANTASTIC. Even if you decide not to stay here, you should come check out the roof. 360 views of the city. Great decor. We spent a bit of time up there. Heated and cover, really something to take advantage of year round. -Updated - The hotel really does feel new. It's clean, and I like the modern feel of the hotel-Location - It's a 5 min walk from Penn Station but just far away enough to miss that crazy midtown bustle. The location was a big plus. -Housekeeping - Really did a great jobWhy you should look elsewhere:-Rooms are tiny. We asked for a queen or a king, and were given two doubles. Not sure how they crammed two beds into the room. It faced another building, so no natural light and no views. The beds were so small that when my honey turned over, I had no blanket was was falling off the bed. Horrible sleep. The staff didn't care. The hotel was "sold out". Didn't look like it was sold out. -Staff: I've already alluded to the staff. Maybe we weren't wearing the right clothes, but they acted so rude to us. I was shocked. Here's an example. We were going to a rehearsal dinner that night, and had put our bags in luggage check during the day. When we asked for our bags, it took us 10 mins to find someone to actually help us (front desk wanted no part of it, and I was sick of them flirting with each other and being snotty), and another 15 mins for them to find our bag, and then another 20 to hail a taxi. We ended up being late to the rehearsal dinner because of the hotel. When I asked and talked to the manager on duty, they said they couldn't find our bags. WHAT??? Crazy. They were so rude to us. Don't they know sites like Trip Advisor exist?This did not feel like a 4 star hotel and the service felt like a 1 star hotel. I'm giving it 3 stars because of the location, updates and rooftop bar. But please, consider booking elsewhere. No one should be treated that rudely at a hotel. One additional note: We actually booked through Hotwire - it was our 2nd time using hotwire, and our last. After we booked we found lower rates on Hilton's site. Hotwire didn't care when we pointed it out to them, and the hotel treated us like 2nd class citizens. We were lured by 4 star boutique hotel. It's not a boutique hotel - just a chain trying something new.

After a nightmare start to booking the Hilton Fashion District via Priceline (trust me - don't go there - they charged me $335 a night when I could have booked the same hotel on the Priceline or Hilton websites at the same time for $275 a night and all complaints fell on deaf ears at Priceline), arriving at the hotel was a fresh start.For those arriving at JFK, take the airtrain then LIRR to Penn Station and from there an easy walk (less than 10 min) to the Hilton Fashion District. The room is exactly as appears on the website, the mini cupcakes were on the reception desk, the in-room coffee makers are there, and there were two bottles of water and a nicely boxed chocolate waiting in my room. The bar on the rooftop is indeed lovely for a drink with a view of the Empire State Building. Reception staff are efficient and friendly enough. The downsides: the gulag mini bar where all items are held to ransom is annoying, no fridge of any kind to store a drink or fruit is painful, and toiletry items are replaced randomly some days and not others. Being my first overseas trip with an ipad - no wifi in room is something I will avoid in future but the two PC's in the lobby came in really handy. Renovations going on next door were noisy - but not overly intrusive.Having arrived after the long haul flight from Melbourne in the evening, I was looking forward to a bit of TV before lights out. The TV in my room wasn't working and two phone calls and two hours later I gave up. A request left with reception the next morning saw the problem fixed by the time I returned that afternoon along with a cute chocolate hammer from the maintenance folk - nice touch.The hotel is in a great midtown location - nearby places to eat include Eataly, Shake Shack, Stumptown (at the Ace Hotel - Melbourne folk need good coffee!), and the night markets next to Madison Square where you can pick up a Momofuku cookie).

What a surprisingly great hotel! I was greeted outside the door, check-in was a breeze and the staff is very polite and helpful. Room was decorated very modern and bed really comfortable. We ate at the restaurant they have called RARE, excellent food a bit pricey but good also the rooftop bar is lovely. They even let me keep my luggage after I checked out because my flight didn't leave till 8 PM. I will be back.

Stayed here on a business trip mid-week. Lobby was busy but check-in was quick and friendly. Rooms are a little small, as mentioned by others but a little larger than those a the W on Times Square. Hotel is modern and fairly stylish for it's size. Stylish bar off the lobby with attentive services and a good selection of beers on tap. The rate for our short lead time reservation was very reasonable for NYC.We didn't eat at the hotel restaurant but it was convenient, clean and fairly well staffed at breakfast. Thats where the fun ended as my coworkers oatmeal was served half cold and my two-eggs-over easy were over really easy. Downright slimy and uncooked. I asked for bacon and got sausage that was--you guessed it--cold/undercooked. The waiter said he'd make it right, but our alotted time for breakfast before our appointment was shot. At least the coffee was OK. But seriously...how hard is breakfast? Oatmeal and eggs...?So....I think the rooms are very good, clean and fresh. Good bathroom hardware and shower. Very good bar to meet up with your posse before heading out. Restaurant was very below par during our stay.

Convenient location to Fashion Institute, Penn Station and shopping. Rooms are clean and well appointed, bed was super comfortable and staff was wonderful. Our room (1508) had a nice view of the Empire State building as did the roof top bar. Would recommend this hotel to anyone staying in NYC!

Figured since this was a new Hilton it would be nice, but it's pretty mediocre (learned that while it is new as a Hilton, it has been two other hotels prior to opening this year as a Hilton).The rooms are typically small for New York. Liked the bathroom (other than the cheap towels) and the Keurig coffee maker, however the bed was awful - back still hurts. Clearly these are cheap mattresses from whatever hotel this was before. Biggest issue was the staff - either indifferent, incompetent, or rude - though did have a drink in the bar and the waitress up there was very good/nice. I'm a Hilton Diamond member, so have higher expectations - I typically am cautious about older Hiltons - some are great (like the one in Copenhagen), but some are just awful - have been staying a lot at Starwood Hotels of late and a Hilton stay makes me appreciate Starwood even more for their consistency
staff are awesome - room and location are great!!!but again with the 15.00 a day for wiifii

This hotel is at a great location near the fashion institute. Easy walking to 5th avenue shopping, up to times square and down to soho. Clean and spacious rooms and the staff was very friendly and helpful.What blew us away was their service:We had booked the room months in advance and when we showed up the people staying in our room didnt check out yet. They apologized and got us a room at another hotel and paid for cab fare to get there.When we got back the next day, they upgraded our room so we had a view of the Empire State Building, gave us breakfast vouchers and a bottle of wine. They went above and beyond which was greatly appreciated. I would definitely stay here again.

Pros:Clean. Great location. Good beds. Courteous and helpful staff. Cheesecake from room service was to die for.Neutral: Rooms a little small but we weren't in there much. Slightly noisy in the a.m. with closing doors heard in the hallway. Leaving fan on in room took care of that.Cons: You have to order ice from room service which turns into PAYING FOR ICE unless you want to look like a tool if you don't tip. The design in the shower was annoying; you have to step under the shower head to reach over and turn it on. That's just silly.

Central location, new, clean rooms - art work is naf but as if that matters! Windows open for fresh air, nice coffee machine in room.Only con - the bathroom didn't have a great exhaust so if you are going to try and put make up on in a hurry, it's pretty hot - but that is just a minor thing.

I have stayed here twice for business and come back because of the the cleanliness, nice staff and reasonable prices. The rooms are typical of a chain hotel but not all dinged up like most NYC hotels get (which grosses me out). The front desk if efficient and very friendly, as are the doormen. There always seems to be someone available to offer assistance and SMILE at you - so, so rare these days, especially in New York. Location is great for anything West side, Chelsea, Fashion District. A Whole Foods is right around the corner, as are several coffee shops and places to eat. I was on the 9th floor in front of the elevator and it was still pretty quiet. Bed very comfy, room was a normal size, not too small.

made res online, had only 2 specific requests. room face empire state building shower over tub. reservation guaranteed us yes, 2 double bed on higher fl that we paid extra for will have view of empire state building will def be shower over tub. we get there, no view (none of their 2 bed rooms have view of empire building), no shower over tub (none of their 2 bed rooms have shower over tub). mentioned to short brunette @ front desk that res confirmed our requests, she said "oh, what res saids isnt our responsibility cause thats not us." is she serious? no offer of giving us options or see what they can do for this error. after checkout, left our bags w front desk. came back in rush cause was rush hour to JFK and pouring rain. need our bags asap. theres 3 girls at front desk (catherine, christinia angelica?). tall girl on phone, blond girl w hair tied back & same dark hair brunette just standing behind desk. give our ticket to girl w blond hair, she gives to bag check guy. he went to load bags for another group. 2 guys came down for their bags after us, gives their ticket to doorman, he got their bags asap gets them a taxi. we're still waiting, asks blond girl for our bags. she said he's busy, then walks away & starts flirting, making faces & laughing w this guest. seriously? we ask brunette for our bags. she saids only bag check guy can get bags. the bag room is right next to the front desk, your one bag check guy is busy. so instead of helping, everyone stands there doing nothing. this is customer services? we went to ask bag check guy ourselves for our ticket so we can get our gas. he saids fine, comes in gets our bags and expects us to tip him. is this hotel for real? no more of this place, such sad service during this economic times and we had other choices too.

PROS:hotel is brand new, nothing is worn looking, all very fab!Beds comfortableGreat Views (from high floors)free mini cupcakes upon check inGreat location, super close to Penn StationThe room service staff was so nice! CONS:Shower poorly laid out... no way to turn on the water without getting soaked! Rooms are smallTINY GYM - one elliptical, one bike, two treadmills, some free weights - with three people in the gym, there was no space to do a sit upI will certainly be back! Compared to the Double Tree, Four Points, and Affinia in the neighborhood - this hotel really is a good one for it's price point.

Staying at this newer - opened 18 months ago - Hilton right now. I'm gazing at The Empire State Building from our room on the 20th floor with amazing views. This is a new, smaller, hipper style hotel for Hilton, more akin to a W Hotel but without the pretentiousness. I'm not a huge fan of the decor, but it wasn't designed for people like me - lovers of everything old world - in mind. Nonetheless everything functions very well.The rooms while small - actually slightly above average in size for nyc - have been very smartly designed and lack for nothing. They also feature an industrial power a/c unit that can keep the room freezing cold. Bathrooms are well laid out and efficient.The staff has been excellent. Always efficient and friendly. My only two slight complaints: 1) the elevators take too long to come - they must not have installed enough for the traffic, and 2) the security guard in the lobby for the rooftop bar - seems a tad pretentious.Otherwise, Hilton fashion district is another fine addition to the world's best hotel family.
user_name:
EdinDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I was really pleasantly surprised by the Hilton New York Fashion District. First the price - with AAA discount, $ 139 for a Friday night in a great location in Manhattan. Second, the style and vibe of the place - you might think of a midtown Manhattan Hilton to be very corporate and bland. Quite the contrary, the hotel had a great deal of style and a great trendy vibe. My room - while small (not a surprise in Manhattan) - was really comfortable, stylish, spotless, and looked like it had been recently renovated. I thought the location - on 26th near 7th Ave - was great, close to the subway, and a short walk from great restaurants and nightspots of lower Manhattan.There was also a great rooftop bar with fantastic views of the city.This place does not the raves of many more well known Manhattan hotels. But the price of those places is easily triple what I paid. This place to me is really undiscovered, great value in the center of Manhattan.
user_name:
travelfan725
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My wife and I spent last Friday & Saturday night at the hotel and was very impressed with the very gracious staff. Not one employee (doorman, housekeeper, server, desk person, maintenance person) walked by or allowed us to walk by without greeting us and wishing us a nice day, afternoon, evening etc.The hotel is very new, clean, and well maintained. The location was very convenient for our purposes, but the neighborhood was not outstanding nor offer varied dining choices without a notable walk. The in-house bar and restaurant is nice and the servers and managers very gracious, but when you are in the city you want to have options.Overall, the staff and facility was great, neighborhood so-so, breakfast was outstanding, drinks were good, and room modern and amenity-laden.

Hotel was amazing! Great location and excellent staff that was accommodating from check-in to check-out. The rooftop bar is awesome and definitely a must-see. We had breakfast daily and the food and service were outstanding. If we ever needed something, it wasn't hard to ask someone that was willing to accommodate and help.It was raining during our trip and the staff (thank you Elle!) even arranged an umbrella prior to our arrival, great service! Definitely will return.

The location of this Hilton is convenient, close to the 1 train. We were very disappointed upon arrival when our reserved top floor double room was reduced to the 8th floor. All we were offered as a condolence was free WI-Fi -which any decent hotel should offer for free anyway! I'm a HHonor member and booked directly though the hotel, bummer that that holds no weight. We were explained that they are fully booked as of last night, but i made reservations two weeks before, why is that my problem?The price was comparable at $259, but $300 with taxes (beware for all NY hotels, taxes are high).The Rooms: Clean and compact with comfy bedding. Bathrooms are clean and although small, not uncomfortable, the BIG problem was it smelled of MOLD and we even saw some in the shower. The hyped up rooftop bar is actually closed, not open as in the pictures. The concept doesn't work in my opinion, but the view is incredible and the drinks are decent. This is a solid choice for a NYC hotel, but I expected a bit more from a Hilton to be honest.

As I get older I am placing a higher value on quiet rooms. This hotel room I had was not quiet. The fan in the a/c would turn off and on even though I had it turn on high and not auto. I was put near the elevator and heard it arrive, depart, hear how much fun the occupants were going to have. I was also on the third floor and my view was nothing. Thank you Hilton for treating a diamond member like talc.

Stayed 5 nights. Decent hotel, rooms were clean and quite spacious for 1 person on business. Good rooftop bar, restaurant was OK if a bit "beef" oriented. Breakfast was tasty if a bit limited. Location for us was perfect between downtown & uptown, easy to get everywhere.As a corporate hotel goes, it is a decent choice.

The service attitude and friendliness of the hotel staff is excellent. Especially the bell boys Jose and Brandon will do everything to make your stay special. Hotel location is good with metro stations nearby and within walking distance to times square. Rooms are nicely decorated and clean. It is the personal attention of the staff and management that makes this place rise above other hotels.

Can't say enough great things about the staff at this hotel. Leonard went out of his way to make sure that we were equipped to hit the streets with great sightseeing information and very helpful suggestions. Rooms were cozy and clean and we all slept great. Hotel is fairly close to the Metro line and so transportation was never an issue. I would recommend this hotel to anyone wanting to visit the big city.

This was our first time at this Hilton location and in typical form the staff was welcoming, warm and wonderful. We were greeted at the curb with assistance unloading our bags, welcomed at the desk, escorted to our room and shown how to operate the elevator with our card, checked in on to see if there was anything we needed and greeted as went out for the evening. Breakfast restaurant staff were friendly, prompt and courteous. We had a great stay, the rooms are clean, comfortable and creatively artsy. Will definitely stay here again since the rooftop bar looks great but we did not make it there. If this hotel not available for your stay in the city they have other accomodations in Chelsea area in Hilton Garden, Hampton and DoubleTree all with the same Hilton Flair for courteous service!

This was our favorite boutique hotel during our honeymoon! Luckily it ended our honeymoon with fashion & style on our final night in NYC. The staff was friendly & accommodating. The room was perfect & clean! The location was superb! The hotel ranks 5 stars easily! We loved the whole experience & definitely a night to remember!!

Rooms are fine, in-room dining average, but the piece that really makes you think you're being ripped off is the internet access of $14.95 a day.In this age, when we all know that the entire hotel access probably costs less than $14.95 a day, it is a slap in the face to be charged so much.From now on I'll be staying at one of the multitude of hotels that have decided not to gouge their customers, and offer free internet.
My girlfriend and I had a great stay at this hotel. The roof top bar was amazing and we couldn't of asked for better accommodations.

The Pros:* Decent hotel located in a really fun part of town. * Every staff member I encountered was incredibly nice and accommodating, from the folks at the front desk, to the elevator attendants, to the food service staff. They all seemed to really enjoy their jobs, and it showed!* Check in and check out was a breeze. * The mini cupcakes at the front desk were such a nice touch! Absolutely delicious. The Cons: * Each time I showered, I had to mop up the floor afterward, as the water leaked out through the bottom of the shower door. * The ironing board is dorm-room size. * There are no vending machines in this hotel (I called the front desk to confirm), so for a drink of water, I had to take the $4.50 Evian from the mini bar in my room. * The fitness center center consists of only two treadmills, one elliptical, one bicycle, and some free weights. I expected a much larger fitness facility.All in all, my stay was okay, but for a four-star, almost $400/night hotel, I expected a little better.

Unassuming hotel within easy walking distance to Madison Square Park, Flatiron Building, Madison Square Garden, Empire State Building and 34th Street shopping area. The decor is fashion themed - multi-coloured mural made of thread spools in lobby, mannequins in front window and sewing themed prints in hotel rooms. Interestingly there is no sewing kit provided!My daughter and I had room 1103 with 2 double beds. Very comfortable. Roomy. Tiny closet but adequate for a weekend stay. Has a safe inside. Nice bathroom although the sink leaks - solved by placing the waste basket underneath. Bite sized cupcakes at reception was a very delicious touch!! The Biggest disappointment in this day and age is that they charge for internet connection - quite unusual for most equivalent hotels.

Last time I stayed here I had a few complaints, one of them being that the staff were unfriendly and another involving the menu choices. Both have got better which was great to see.Check-in was swift, friendly and effortless. Just what I need after a red eye flight.Once again I enjoyed a few drinks at the rooftop bar, Rare View. It's really worth going to see the Empire State Building lit up against the New York skyline. Spectacular. I wish the bar served food or even snacks - I would have stayed there longer if it did.I had a good meal at the ground floor Rare bar. The service was excellent and the menu much better than last time with a good variety of healthy foods as well as the usual burger & fries type dishes.The rooms are very small which can be a surprise if you're not expecting that. The hotel also feels very corporate, largely due to the clientele and business meetings that go on there, so it wouldn't beat my "go to" New York hotels like the Andaz or Peninsula. But for the price and excellent location I would stay here again and recommend it for business and vacation travelers.

Recently I had a group of people from New Zealand staying and I was tour host. One of our group got sick, from the first moment we arrived nothing was too much trouble, from providing a wheel chair, to staff from reception, hotel manager, security and waiters. Everyone was so helpful. They made every effort and endeavoured to make our stay a fantastic one. We would highly recommend this hotel and salute the staff for going above and beyond.

On my most recent trip to New York, decided to stay somewhere other than Times Square...and after looking up reviews on Trip Advisor, and determining where I'd be traveling to in NYC, thought I'd give Hilton NY Fashion Dist. a try. It blends in well with the neighborhood...but is distinguished by the fashionably dressed mannequins in the front window. Check in went very smoothly...and I was soon on my way to my room. On the 14th floor...the main view was the office building next door....which was fine...didn't come there for the view. And actually on one evening, found one of the "offices" had a bit of martial arts training going on. The room was very comfortable, if small...but didn't spend a lot of time in the room anyway. Loved the amenities in the bathroom...and loved the eco-friendly lighting as well. The Hotel also offers a restaurant and rooftop bar, neither of which I visited...but both seemed to be pretty busy. On the corner was a nice tea bistro...Argo, I believe...used it several times, because the hotel charged more than 14 dollars for WiFi....Argo only required that you buy a beverage...most under the 14 dollar price range. :)  The Hotel is about a block away from the Fashion Institute...and several blocks away from Madison Square Garden. Both easy walking distance from the Hotel. And there were numerous restaurants and bistros in the area as well. There always seemed to be a taxi in front of the Hotel...and when I left very early in the morning for the airport, one was available. The price of the rooms were reasonable...and I would recommend using this Hilton, next time you visit.

Quick two night business visit. From the doorman to guest reception team and management nothing but a warm and generous reception. All the staff was extremely helpful with whatever requests or questions we had. Rave Rooftop is awesome and the bar at lobby level is very inviting. Location to my areas of interest and business needs were easily accommodated at this Hilton location. Solid mix or guests from business to family.

Stayed at Hilton New York Fashion District for 4 nights in September with a friend of mine. I don't have any experience with other hotels in the area, but I consider it to be a good alternative from what I have seen online comparing standard, location and price. The size of the room was a pleasant surprise after what we have heard a lot about tiny rooms on Manhattan, two huge beds and decent space around. The location is great, walking distance to quite a few attractions on central Manhattan and just a short walk to subway stations with good connectivity for the rest of the city. Decent restaurant as well, we had burgers on our first night there. As the only minor complaint i can remember, paying extra for a room at a high floor wasn't worth it. Although we stayed at 15th floor, the buildings close by are a lot higher so there is no view anyway...

We stayed here overnight on Labor Day weekend. The fashion design theme is threaded (ahem) throughout the hotel and very tastefully done - the chairs in the lobby look like spools of thread, and spools are featured in the lobby artwork as well. The quote "Sew, a needle pulling thread" (from the Sound of Music) is framed in each bedroom. As far as accommodations: the bed was comfortable, the room was a nice size and the bathroom was clean and modern. The view of Manhattan's rooftops and the Empire State Building from our 20th floor room was spectacular, and we were grateful for the blackout curtains when it was time to turn in. This hotel is about a 10 minute walk to the High Line Park. Several restaurants are within walking distance as well. For a treat, there were free samples of mini cupcakes in the lobby.

We stayed here the weekend of oct 7- 9th...The hotel lobby was beautiful....our room was clean and an average size room...we were only in there to sleep...the bathroom was modern and fresh towels everyday....Over all this hotel was a true 4 star....will definately stay here again and also suggest this hotel to everyone.....The hotel is centrally located and if you want to experience true italian culinary experience check out Eataly located on 5th and 200 street.

We were really looking forward to staying in this hotel for our trip in Sep '11 but some of the previous reviews had me concerned. Here are the Pros & Cons so I can let you make up your own mind.Pros:- The room was always very clean & tidy (thank you to the maids)- The staff were always very polite & pleasant (apart from one but will come to that later)- View was excellent (will come on to the issue with room allocation)- Good location- The night security guard was outstanding ! Believe his name was Leon (apologies if I've got your name wrong). He went above & beyond on numerous occasions & was a really smashing helpful guy, thank you !Cons:- Sadly the thing lasting memory I have of this hotel is that there was a mistake with our room bill where some drinks had been added that were not ours. When I brought this up with the girl on reception she tried to make out we were lying & tried to cross examine my partner. How dare she ! We spent a fortune on our holiday & the last thing we would do is try & get out of paying our bill. If I was going to try to get out of paying for something it would have been for the room service where they charged us $57 for two sub standard burgers & chips - Paid extra for a 'city view' room & was initially given a room looking into somebody's office. When I phoned reception they said a city view room isn't guaranteed but they would change our room (if its not guaranteed then how can you charge extra for it ?)- The safe in our room decided to lock us out one morning for some reason. Called reception but they said we would have to wait for a engineer to start work which was fine but we had a early morning train to catch to Washington & all our cash & cards were in the safe ! Got it resolved but only by the skin of our teeth- $15 a day for wifi. Come on guys it used to be free until Hilton took over the hotel- The roof top bar gives the impression of being 'open top' but it wasn't & whilst the view is very good the bar isn't.- Ordered room service as we were pressed for time one evening. An hour later it still hadn't arrived so called down to check its status & they had forgotten our orderThe hotel is a bit hit & miss. It certainly has potential but it seems to keep letting its self down.

Stayed here in October 2011, very nice room on 18th floor. Good walking distance from most areas. room 1814 was spacious, the biggest i've ever had in new york. Didn't eat in the hotel as there are plenty of places nearby. It was a business trip with plenty of meetings in the hotel bar which is great for the purpose, WiFi $15 a day but plenty quick enough for most purposes, used my "skype type" connection to the UK a lot. Big flat screen TVs and good coffee machines. Staff are helpful and very good, I will return and bring back my family. Try the rooftop bar open 5pm, some great views.

This hotel is a great place to stay. The staff and service is great. I have been coming to NYC for a long time and would recommend this hotel for business and leisure. Great location and having a patio to people watch on the street is always a good experience.MAJF

Great neighbourhood if you hate the crowd of Times Square like I do and love the ambiance of Chelsea, the Village and Meatpacking District like I do. Great service, all employees greeted us with a smile. I read some reviews here that said that they could hear everything what happened behind walls and it took ages to take the elevator. I spent 3 nights here in room 1209 just in front of the elevator and that never ever happened to me. Rooms are small but the bed it's so comfy that I didn' care about room space. Closet is tiny so it's better to keep clothes on the luggage. Coffee and tea for free in the room and delicious mini cupcakes for free in the lobby are a nice touch. Wi-fi isn't for free in the room. I thought that was a drawback at first but then I was happy that I could stay a bit disconnected. And there are 2 computers in the lobby I could use to surf the web. Don't hesitate to stay here!

It is an absolut great Hotel! The rooms are modern an totally clean!! The location is in the heart of NYC and the Fashion district a wonderful part of manhattan! I can 100% recommand this hotel! Especially the service is outstanding....(by the way @ Elle: thanks again for your brilliant surprise!!:o)We will definitely come back!!!

Opening in early 2011, the 'Fashion District Hilton' is a reasonably priced modern hotel in a convenient location. Featuring a rooftop partially open-air bar that overlooks midtown Manhattan, the Hilton is a short walk to Times Square and within longer walking distance (for those who like to explore a city by foot) to Central Park and the excellent shopping of Soho. We booked a Queen Bed High Floor room and, while checked into a not-so-high floor room (overlooking a wall opposite our window) with two double beds (not a queen) after arriving after midnight on the first night, we were put in a more applicable room for the remaining 5 nights after speaking to the front desk. The new room was as-anticipated, however we were not informed about the type of room we were given for night one when we were checked in by the attendant and had to go through the process of moving rooms the following morning, being inconvenienced through no fault of our own.Our (2nd) room was close to the top floor and overlooked the Empire State building: a view worth paying extra for. Including a desk, storage cupboard, safe and tidy modern bathroom (with shower over bathtub), the 'standard' mini fridge was strangely absent. Replaced by a tiny fridge-sized vending machine, there was no way to store food or chill beverages purchased from one of the many nearby stores. Instead, we were restricted to over-priced beer and peanuts-in-a-can. Having nowhere to store fresh fruit from a market casued the fruit to go mouldy within 24 hours, a pity since most travellers know it's nice to not be limited to eggs and pancakes every morning one is in the US of A.The room was made-up each morning but with a little inconsistency. Not all glasswear was replaced/cleaned each day and the coffee station, while welcome (despite it being of the high-wastage 'capsule' variety) was not restocked particularly well. The in-room TV was excellent, providing a guide of what was on every station (making looking for the weather and business channels easier) in addition to other information that was useful. The downstairs restaurant, Rare, was excellent. Serving upscale burgers, amongst other 'grill' fare, the meal had here was great. Pure Americana, a spicy buffalo wings appetizer was finger-lickin' good while gourmet burgers accompanied by a basket full of different types of fries (sweet potato, french, lattice) and their respective dipping sauces were suculent and delicious. Having avoided fast-food burgers prior to visiting Rare, it was a joy to taste a burger crafted by a chef.Overall, this Hilton's best traits lie in its location and newness. Many Manhattan hotels feel tired and while this one continues to feel new, it has that distiction. Being central while not in the dead-centre of touristy Times Square was also good. A walk to Times Square took only 5-10 leasurely minutes, and sites such as the Empire State, the high-line park (a must-see!) were also close-by. Normally you'd take the subway to Soho, but gridlock caused us to walk the 30-odd blocks (with bags of shopping) and it was a fun way to see more of the city.Related tip: Don't pass-up the delicious CHIPOTLE mexican grill on the corner of 26th & 7th. If you can work out the read from right-to-left menu, you're in for a cheap treat.

rooms are cramped... i dont know how other reviewers can claim the rooms are large. the bed was the weakest point---the mattresses are cheap, springy, and motel quality.breakfast was surprisingly good. it is alacarte rather than a buffet.service throughout is excellent. very cheery and personable staff.

Absolutely nothing wrong with this hotel...just not great. It's in a central location but there's nothing very exciting nearby. We were able to walk pretty much everywhere - from Penn Station, to Highline Park, back from East Village etc.The room was clean and well-appointed, and they made an effort to give the room a trendy edge. I don't like that the bar-fridge in the room can't be used for personal items - it's basically a vending machine fridge. The air-con was pretty noisy. After a day of pounding the pavement, exploring NYC, I would have loved to lie back in a bath but there was only a shower, no bath tub. So, I would rate this between average and good, but Tripadvisor only allows "Very Good" which it wasn't. I guess next time I visit NYC I'll be sure to choose a neighborhood with a bit more of a vibe.

I only stayed here for one night on a business trip. Hilton has a reputation that most chain hotels suffer from: that of being characterless and bland. Certainly there is a uniformity to these hotels, but this particular hotel had a good vibe about it. My room was quiet and well appointed, with a very comfy bed and large walk around in shower. I also had dinner in the restaurant, and was delighted by the quality and cooking. The hotel, which is midtown, is a good location to explore the city. Finally, the price. I paid $145 for the night which I think this is very good value.

I booked this hotel last minute via Hilton reservations when I missed my train out of New York. Around midnight, I rolled into the hotel with no luggage, or anything for a night's stay. The front desk staff was very helpful and right after I went up to my room, a bellman delivered a travel toothbrush and toothpaste.Positives: Convenient location, virtually brand-new furnishings, reasonable price. Excellent bed and bedding. The room was compact, but seemed just fine for the price. Negatives: Walls seem thin--- overheard way too much of an exuberant girlfriends' getaway next door. Design overkill: hard to decode the light switch in the bathroom. The service orientation of the front desk really set this hotel apart from my other recent stays at New York hotels. Great staff at the hotel. This is an excellent new hotel option in this area. Lots of the Chelsea/Midtown hotels are either way overpriced for the leisure traveler or economical but very rundown and even seedy.

I've stayed at this Hilton about 5 times and even before it became a Hilton (was a Wyndham) and it's always perfect. Rooms are large, very well appointed and nicely decorated with some Fashion District touches. The touchless card entry devices to unlock the doors and the elevators is cool and very makes you fell safe. There is a nice gym and a very good restaurant in this hotel. If you "wanna be seen", there is always the rooftop bar where you can have a drink and chat with nice people. This location is great in a very cool part of the city. If you're willing to spend a little extra money for yout NYC trip, go to this hotel.

Location was excellent -- central to everything. I walked to lower Manhattan, Soho, Union Square, Rockefeller Center and Times Square easily from this location. I didn't eat in the neighborhood excenpt for occasional bagels around the corner. The room was gorgeous and stylish. Front desk staff were young and hip, and very accommodating when I pointed out how noisy the room was. After being moved several floors up, I slept much better.

I stayed for a week with my teen nephews. Location was absolutely perfect for us, specially because we were more likely to spend time downtown - Soho, Nolita, Tribeca, Village. We could go walking distance to almost everywhere and there were two major subway lines. Staff was nice and helpful. Negative aspects - no in-room free wi-fi, my king bed room was ridiculously small and closet was almost inexistent.

My husband and I stayed one night at this hotel for our wedding anniversary. The hotel made a special point of congratulating us and making sure we had a pleasant stay. Very nice touch! The hotel staff is very friendly and professional; obviously, great management. Our room was compact and a bit noisy (street noise), but it is NYC. The room was clean and newly renovated. The roof top bar was great. Very easy to get taxis - no line and immediate availability - which is a huge plus.

I stayed for two nights this past June (Friday and Saturday nights). My only interaction with an employee was at check-in. I was never greeted when coming back into the hotel. There was a separarte elevator for the roof deck bar. If people were heading there they were treated very nicely. The room was tiny- which was expected. I was bummed that my wireless connection did not work and I had to pay for the hotel's. Also while the bathroom was very nice and new, it had the loudest toliet flush I've ever heard. I jumped each time! Also, a lovely glass shower but no tub. I stayed here at a decent rate but if I had to pay high rates I might chose a different hotel. P.S. I did enjoy the cupcake treats at the front desk which were great!

This is the loudest hotel I have ever stayed at in NYC (even for the location). Even with earplugs I couldn't sleep. There's a club directly opposite the hotel, lots of cabs, people shouting and construction near by. Added to this, the hotel staff seem to be moving carts up and down the corridor (loudly) at all hours of the night. The sound proofing on the windows is so bad, I had to double-check that I didn't accidentally leave them open.I requested a new room and was told it was possible to move, so I packed all my belongs. Confirmed the next morning and again in the afternoon with the front desk that the move was all set. I was told to just leave my packed bag by the door and everything would be moved when it came back. When I returned to the hotel they told me that my things weren't packed so they couldn't move me. I insisted everything was ready to go, they then said it was poor communication on their side and that they said they would move my room the next day. When I returned to my room, I called the front desk again to confirm the move (next day) and they sounded surprised and said they would put in a move request for me.

As usual with my NYC trips, I booked this hotel based on room rate and location. The hotel is new and modern and any Ikea fan will feel right at home there. The location was excellent - we stayed there for several days, ventured both north to Central Park and south to Tribeca (not on the same day) and never once got on the subway. Do avoid the bar adjacent to the hotel - way overpriced, plenty of better alternatives nearby.
user_name:
SLJack
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed at the Fashion 26 Hotel New York for four nights and would definately return. After reading the good reviews we were excited for the break. When we arrived we were not disappointed.We got a yellow cab from the airport to the hotel and felt instantly welcome. The room and bathroom were exceptionally clean, along with the rest of the hotel. The beds were extremely big and comfortable and we heard no outside noise. We didn't have a great view outside (we were backed on to another block), however, we were rarely in the room throughout the day so a fantastic view was not essential. The only negative was that we had room service for our breakfast every morning which got quite expensive. The food was really good though.The hotel staff were extremely helpful and the roof top views were incredible. There was a bar on the roof with fantastic views of the city, we especially loved going up there at night with all the lit up buildings. The location was perfect and the best place to be when taking a sight- seeing holiday. It was central to everything and only a 5 minute walk from the nearest subway. We found it incredibly easy to get around from this location. Overall, we loved the whole experience and would love to go back again. The location was perfect, the staff were helpful and friendly, one of the best holidays we have been on.

We picked this hotel for its proximity to Penn Station, where we arrived in NY, and the West Village where we attended a family function. Each were just a few minutes' walk, and the hotel neighborhood is nice and quiet. Our room (which we got cheap, considering the location, on Priceline) was small and no-frills but perfectly comfortable for one night, and all the furnishings and decor were nice & new. The check-in staff were genuinely friendly, and other staff who we encountered in the lobby and elevator offered us various tips about the hotel. We would definitely stay here again and recommend it as an appealing choice on the middle- to lower-west side.

We stayed at this hotel in Sept 5th, 2011 for one night with my family, two room. It's a pretty good hotel, The rooms are small as well as the hallway from the elevator. There are no good views out of the room windows as the buildings that surround this hotel is equally tall. Our room was on the 18th floor and the elevators are fast. It has a roof top bar that you can get a good view of New York. I don't know what the view looks like as we didn't get a chance to go up there, but there was a hugh picture of the view outside of the hotel. We went to New York to Tour it and see Time Square. It's about 12 blocks from the hotel and it was pretty safe to walk back to the hotel from Time Square though. Valet parking is fifty five per day plus 10 per valet call. Every time you call valet to bring your car, they charge you ten dollars extra which I though was crazy. You can self park a couple of blocks down from the hotel into a garage but there it's (I think) fourty five dollars. I think that most all hotels would charge for parking in New York. Next time, I would highly check out other hotels at or very close to Time Square as you can walk out of your hotel and be in the center of everything but be ready for pay for it and that also goes for the resturants around Time Square. I don't know what the prices of other hotels are but the Hilton cost us around ninty five a day. We were there on Monday (labor Day) so it may be more or less on weekends. The hotel is very clean, the beds are comfortable, has a flat panel tv, in room coffee. The room didn't have a tub only a shower. The hotel has a roof top bar and restaurant but didn't drink or eat there. I did get a can of beer from the hotel room bar for seven dollars. Don't know why it's caled Fashion District as we didn't see anything other than the usuall shops, restaurants, ect around this hotel. If you need more info on this hotel, feel free to contact me and I will do my best.

I've stayed at many of the Hilton properties in NYC but this was my first time here. It was a welcomed change. The place is very new, up-to-date, clean and in a good spot. It'sconvenient to multiple subway lines and even an easy walk to numerous restaurants and bars. The rooms are modern, very spacious, comfortable, spotless and have everything required. I was hoping to get to the rooftop bar, Rare View (attached to the hotel) but it wasn't open yet. However, I did get to grab a quick bite and some drinks in the bar (Rare Bar & Grill) and it's not your average hotel fare. It's a great spot!I'll stay here again.

I love this hotel. I stayed here when it was the Fashion 26 two years ago and it is every bit as good now. Okay, so the free cupcakes are smaller than they used to be, but you can make up for that by taking two :) This time I made the mistake of staying at another hotel first but luckily I was able to move to this hotel. My room, which was on the larger side by New York standards, was meticulously maintained and felt luxurious. The decor is modern and the darker colors are calming. The bathroom is beautiful and they supply you with Peter Thomas Roth products. I called the front desk when I locked myself out of the room safe and staff was there within 5 minutes to help me open it. Since you need your room key to access the elevator, you feel secure in your room and on your floor. There is room service from the restaurant downstairs if you feel like staying in. The front desk staff and the doormen are friendly and helpful. The hotel is located on a fairly quiet street only minutes walking distance from Penn Station or Broadway. This is a perfect place to stay if you are traveling alone, with others, or for business.

I stayed immediately before Hurricane Irene. The elevator set up was slow and annoying, with one reserved for the bar and one that didn't seem to be in use at all. The minibar instead of a refrigerator was useless, particularly as there are no ice machines and the ice I requested when I checked in hadn't arrived by the time I checked out. The coffee maker/minibar area was lit up with no apparent on/off switch, so it glowed all night long. The television had only basic cable and WiFi was $15 per day. The worst was the night of August 26, when airlines began to announce flight cancellations. I called the front desk to ask if I could extend my stay rather than check out as planned on August 27. I was told they would check and call me back. Thirty minutes later, I still hadn't received word so I called again and was told they were not extending any guests and were holding all available rooms for staff. This left me scrambling, after midnight, to find a hotel for the following night. The discourtesy in not extending my stay, and in not even bothering to let me know, was the last straw.

This hotel was awesome. The room was very clean and comfortable. The staff was was very friendly and helpful. The concierge helped me to plan a wonderful tour. I would definately stay again. One of the quietest hotels I have ever stayed in.

I had to register just to review this hotel; this is by far the worst experience I’ve had traveling in the last several years. I’m HH Diamond and Marriott Platinum so I’ve spent a fair amount of time in business hotels. I selected September since it's now 12:10AM on 9/1 and the music is still playing.The staff is nice and courteous but that doesn’t make up for the shortcomings.As previously stated the rooms are very small with only showers. I was staying two nights in the middle of the week; I booked a king room on a high floor and upon check-in I asked if there was an upgrade available at which point I was told that I had been upgraded to a king room on a high floor…. Funny since that’s what my reservation was already for. When I got to the room I found a very small (even by large city standards) but clean room with a view directly into the office across the street (17th floor doesn’t come close to clearing the neighboring buildings so the only positive to a higher floor is less traffic noise). I asked about the possibility of getting a view and I was told I should have requested the North side of the hotel. Now I’ve never stayed at this hotel and as a diamond member I usually get decent rooms. I was however told they would move me to a nicer room the next night since the hotel was full for the night. That’s when the problems really started. I was given a room on the 22nd floor with a beautiful view, the problem is that they neglected to tell me that the night club on the roof stays open until at least Midnight and is quite loud on the 22nd floor. Actually very loud, it was loud enough that my wife could hear it over the phone when I called her at 11:30PM because I still couldn’t sleep (earplugs are no defense against R&B and techno since the bass resonates through everything). I called the front desk and I was told that the next time I should request a room that isn’t on the 22nd floor, it’s amazing that they expect the guests to know so much about the hotel before they come (request a north facing room not on the 22nd floor, got it.). I was also advised that since this was Wed night the club would probably be open until 12:30 or 1am and the front desk was nice enough to point out that it must not be bothering anyone else…. Seriously??? I like loud music at clubs as much as the next person but it really sucks when you have an 8am flight. There is no way that they don’t get nightly complaints about this unless they don’t put people on the 22nd floor or everyone that stays here is out till 1am every night. All in all the experience was far below any Hampton or Homewood I’ve stayed in over the last 5 years and I can guarantee I and my co-workers who were traveling with me will not be back to this hotel.

Upon arrival, the hotel seems compressed and small. Room was small, no bathtub, hardly any room for luggage. We were put into a terrible room with scaffolding outside our window on the second floor. We were moved to a higher floor. We had to order ice, it took almost an hour. Second time we ordered ice, it didnt come at all. Bed/pillows were average.Poor service.

The hotel itself is ok, the rooms are nice and clean, but the service from staff was pretty underwhelming. The guys out the front were great and very helpful but the front desk staff were not overly friendly or helpful. Food at the restaurant was average and expensive, and bar staff were just rude, one server basically threw a drinks menu at us and then didn't acknowledge our questions or requests. So rude. I have always found service in the USA to be good but during this visit something fundamental has changed - we have had bad service across NYC...!!
user_name:
Vespa180
New York City, New York

review_body: According to the staff, fire dept. restrictions limit room occupancy to 2 adults. So if you're traveling with 3 in your party, you'll need 2 rooms. Why it's safer to have 2 adults and 2 children, in a room rather than 3 adults is a mystery. Anyway, it's a new hotel, there were still issues such as the tops of doors which are not even so the doors have to be shoved close and tugged open, which resulted in more noise than was necessary. But the engineering/maintenance staff is superb and immediately responded to this issue. When we checked in we noticed the toilet in our room was stopped up, and when notified, the front desk staff profusely apologized and immediately an engineer appeared at our door and fixed the problem. The staff is very well trained and very responsive. The rooms are typical NY pocket size, while the room rate is high, and the fitness center is tiny, tiny, tiny. But you're in NYC, there's plenty of walking to be done, so there's no excuse for not exercising. We would return to the property on another visit to NYC.

My Wife and I stayed here for one week on our Honeymoon in August 2011. We had booked in January, prior to the hotel becoming part of the Hilton Group.A few months prior to our trip, I contacted the Guest Services Manager, Elle Lee, to arrange flowers and champagne for my wife as a surprise. From first contact, I felt there was nothing that they wouldn’t do for us, and this was carried through by every member of staff we encountered throughout our stay. I’d arranged for roses, rose petals and champagne to be in the room for our check-in, and my wife really liked them.From the guys who helped us unload and then load our luggage in and out of the cars, the staff on reception, the concierge and the bar staff were all friendly and helpful. We used the concierge to book into a couple of restaurants – I knew the name of them and they did the rest. It took us a few days to realise that there were a couple of computers that we could use for free (along with a printer), and once we did we started to use them to find restaurants and information on Broadway shows.Most nights we had a drink or two in Rare Bar before we went out. Again the staff were really friendly and one bartender had remembered what beers I’d already tried from their selection of draft beers. The hostess pointed us in the right direction for the Subway.The room was nicely decorated and we weren’t short of space for our bags, clothes and even when we bought stuff, it didn’t clog the room up. The bed was massive and so comfy. The air-con made it easy to keep the room cool enough for us and the black-out blinds meant that the sun wasn’t waking us up. Our room was directly outside the elevators, and we were never woken by noise from either the elevators or the rooftop bar, and we were on the 19th floor. The bathroom was a good size and the walk-in shower was great.The rooftop bar was nice, but was a bit too trendy for us. There were a lot of New Yorkers in when we went up. I was surprised how loud the music was as we hadn’t heard any noise from anywhere else in the hotel. The view was great; absolutely worth going up and having a drink or two.Overall it is a really great hotel for the price, and the staff helped in making it a little bit more special.

This was the first time I stayed in an extremely modern hotel, and I've got mixed feelings.The decor of the lobby is interesting and really reflects the fact that we're in the fashion district, with an interesting composition made of threads of different color right above the reception desk. The lobby area, however, is extremely small. One more problem is the fact that there is a rooftop club, and at night the line to get to the club is actually right in front one of the three elevators. Bouncer included! So a lot of noise!The room we got was facing the entrance on a low floor and it was very noisy! It took me a long while to fall asleep because of the noises coming from the street. Also, having booked (and paid for) a room with a king size bed, I was given one with a queen. The next day we asked to change and we got a quieter one, upper floor, facing an alley. Overall, ok, but I wouldn't exactly recommend it...

This new Hilton Hotel (it was a series of other brands previously) is well located for Macys and the Empire State Building. It has a fun feel about it. The high floor rooms (we were on the 21st floor) have a good view but I doubt the low down ones see anything at all.The rooms are well appointed and clean but quite tiny. The closets barely hold 10 items.The concierges really did not know the neighborhood and were a complete waste of time regarding ideas for local dining and shops. I asked for a bagel place in the neighborhood and they said there was not a single one and yet I found 2 within 4 blocks. I asked for restaurants west of 9th Ave and they said they did not know of any! There were dozens. I asked for Sushi in midtwon and they enetered the words sushi and midtwon into google - a concierge should know places not use google to find names. I complained to the manager on duty who appologised.
New, clean and close to subways and attractions in NYC

Just returned from New York, had a wonderful stay and wanted to say how helpful the staff were especially the bell boys! One guy really helped us at the end of our stay when our taxi driver didn't show up. Unfortunately I didn't catch his name but he was truly fantastic! We had some missing laundry from our room - which we think was inadvertently thrown away - but the manager was extremely understanding about this and we were compensated by having a complimentary breakfast in our room. The hotel was comfortable with a very trendy rooftop bar which wasn't as accessible as we had hoped but all in all we had a great time. I agree that the mini bar should be changed for a fridge as the temperatures soar in the summer and a fridge would be so useful especially for storing medicines etc. The location was perfect just a few minutes from all the city centre attractions and close to the subway. Thank you to the staff for helping to make the trip so special and to my family who arranged this all for me as a birthday treat !!

It's not the biggest and best but it's clean, modern, and in a trendy area near where I need to be for work. I agree that the mini-bar would better be swapped for a fridge. I had medicine I needed refridgerating and there's no ice available on the floors. It took 10 minutes for a bell-man to bring me a bucket. The shower is also new, clean and modern but water leaks horribly around where the door shuts.Wi-fi is available - I'm using it now. But it can be slow. Five minute walk to Chelsea where we ate dinner at a unique Paella Bar (Socarrat). Fun experience. Decent food.The hotel's root top restaurant was under construction but we did enjoy an appetizer and beverage in a lobby area. Some of the best people watching can be done from here!

The rooms are very very small. For this price, there should also be free WIFI.A very serious shortcoming is the wait at the elevators (only 2 in service for 21 floors!) leads to waiting times of 10 minutes or more.The most serious problem of all was finding our room opened by cleaning before checking out with a previous promise of not to do so. We had received a one hour extension since we were Hilton Honors program members. This is the first time this has ever happened at a Hilton Hotel.Lastly, the noise from the other rooms and especially from the RARE nightclub was unsettling on late Sat. nite and it makes sleep difficult.

Before we always stayed at the Holiday Garden Inn on the 28th Street but as they did not have room for one of the nights decided on this hotelVery happy, beds nice and soft, the room a bit more updated than at the HGI and maybe a touch larger. Bathroom was clean but only had a large shower. Fine with me. Used the rooftop bar once and it is a nice feature. Not sure I would rush to go back but if your here you should try it. Views from the hotel rooms are not great even on the 20th floor as building block the view.Front of house staff very friendly and check in ok.
user_name:
luischable
New York City, New York

review_body: This was our first time at the fashion 26 and we were taking chance because we usually stay at the midtown location. I am now a fan of Hilton 26. The rooms were just ok but I received world class service and hospitality especially from a young man named Brandon. This young man went above and beyond to help us in any way possible. That kind of service will definitely make us here when we return to New York City. Thank you for making our stay worthwhile.

This used to be an independant boutique hotel. I've stayed here three times for biz meetings. Unfortunately, the Hilton front desk service isn't as good as it should be. To make up for this, all the other employees - housekeepers, bell hops, doormen, restaurant et al. - were wonderful. The rooms are small NYC size without much counter space to lay out jewelery & toiletries. Regular stuff like iron, shampoo are provided as you'd expect. They are clean and modern design. Beds & bedding are very comfortable and good quality. You have to pay per-day for internet access. (14.95/day I think). Concierge often isn't at the desk. Lobby is small, awkward and often crowded with restaurant goers, guests, luggage.There isn't a fridge, only a mini-bar that can't be touched without incurring a fee (most "strick" I've ever seen in a hotel room). The rooftop bar is very popular and the food in the restaurant is delicious, though it offers a fairly standard new American fusion menu.

The hotel guests are a mix of tourists and business people which is to be expected. I arrived early (11am) and the front desk offered to hold my bag until my room was ready (4pm). I thought that the room was well-appointed but the door was so thin that I could hear everything that happened in the hall all night long. Surprising, too, since my stay began on a Sunday. I did try to go to the rooftop bar once but guests get little priority and one night it was closed completely for a private event. I booked the room through Tripadvisor and they turned out to have the best rate (even better than AAA) so be sure to give it a shot first!Location was very accessible to Subway and Penn Station. Just a few blocks.

Stayed two nights for a mother/daughter trip and college visit.PROS: Very friendly and helpful staff (even hailed cabs for us), clean room, comfortable beds, nice linens, large shower, location convenient for our planned activities, good in-room coffee/tea maker (Keurig), high-definition TV.CONS: Air conditioner was VERY NOISY so I slept with a pillow over my head. Main complaint: no mini-refrigerator or microwave in the room, something that is pretty standard in most hotels. I called room service for a bucket of ice for our cooler and they never brought it...until I complained about it the next morning. My daughter is vegan so we had stopped at Whole Foods Chelsea (only a couple of blocks away) to get soy yogurt, fruit, and bagels for breakfast. Instead of a fridge, Hilton opted for an overpriced mini-bar. If you drive in, as we did, there is a parking garage on the same block as the hotel.

This hotel is very modern and updated and in a great location. It's easy to walk to Times Square or to catch the subway down the street. The staff was friendly and the rooms were very nice. There was a Keurig coffee maker in the room - very convenient and little mess. I would definitely recommend this hotel.

We just cam back from having a Mother - Daughter trip to New York City. We had a great time. This hotel was located perfectly, very easy to use the subway from this location and it is in within walking distance of Times Square. I wanted to mention a very special Thank you to Brendon the Doorman, he went out of his way to make sure we got a car to take us to the airport and was helpful all week with directions. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel.

Stumbled upon this hotel on expedia - photos looked good, but hotel even better in te flesh. A good 4 star - everything is new and modern, including the comfortable beds, flat screen tv and power shower. The staff and service was amongst the friendliest and best I have experienced in the USA. Additionally, the hotel has an excellent concierge service (complemented by a knowledgable front desk team too) which we used at least once a day, plus the RARE grill restaurant is a hidden gem - great food and reasonably priced.

Friendly employees upon arrival, was able to sit at roof top bar early in the evening but it was always reserved in the evenings. Room was clean and a decent size for a manhattan king room. Overall, I did not have any complaints- and I am really picky when it comes to here I lay my head down at night!
user_name:
JayJay646
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed for one night and enjoyed the experience. New, very comfortable rooms but they are small so would not recommend if you intend to spend a lot of time in the room. However, NY is not for staying in rooms; if this area suits, this hotel is good value for money. The service levels were good and staff helpful and friendly. The roof top bar is fun and gives an unusual Manhattan skyline featuring plenty of wooden water tanks!

My friend and I stayed at this hotel for a "girls weekend" and had a great time. It is brand new, very stylish and sleek, and in a great location - walking distance to the West Village, Madison Square Park, Times Square, etc. The room was pretty large for Manhattan and very comfortable.
